description: The Enabling Office 365 Services - Exam 70-347 show is produced for those preparing for the professional Office 365 certification.  It covers topics that help the professional evaluate, plan, deploy and operating Office 365 services and more.  The viewer will see not only working in the Office 365 Admin center but also some consideration for Office deployment of Office 365 ProPlus, Exchange Online, SharePoint, Skype for Business, Azure AD.  This is designed for someone already experienced in some of the Office 365 products.

episodes.description: The Enabling Office 365 Services - Exam 70-347 show is produced for those preparing for the professional Office 365 certification. It covers topics that help the professional evaluate, plan, deploy and operating Office 365 services and more. The viewer will see not only working in the Office 365 Admin center but also some consideration for Office deployment of Office 365 ProPlus, Exchange Online, SharePoint, Skype for Business, Azure AD. This is designed for someone already experienced in some of the Office 365 products.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.952
[SOUND] Hello, we're here to
introduce you to an exciting new

2
00:00:04.952 --> 00:00:08.435
series starting right here on ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:08.435 --> 00:00:14.270
When we take a look at enabling
Office 365 Services for Exam 70-347.

4
00:00:14.270 --> 00:00:18.068
Now if that's what you're interested in,
you're in the right place, as we take you

5
00:00:18.068 --> 00:00:21.760
through every single exam objective
domain that we have available to us.

6
00:00:21.760 --> 00:00:25.570
Make sure that you do get the details
behind that to get prepared for the exam.

7
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:29.170
Let's take a look at my screen as we take
a look at some of these different details.

8
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:31.760
When it comes down to it
you'll want to go here first.

9
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:35.919
I simply used the search engine and
typed in Exam 70-347 and

10
00:00:35.919 --> 00:00:39.420
that led me to Microsoft's
official exam page.

11
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:44.630
For this particular exam, and
in US dollars it's $165.00 US dollars

12
00:00:44.630 --> 00:00:47.600
that you'll have to pay to be
able to sit for this exam.

13
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:49.800
So make sure you check out
whatever the details and

14
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:53.770
the costs are in your region, and
that will also help you out too.

15
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:58.360
Now, this page is not only of course,
about having to pay for the exam and

16
00:00:58.360 --> 00:01:01.420
register for the exam and schedule,
and everything that you need to do.

17
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:02.390
But it's right here,

18
00:01:02.390 --> 00:01:06.710
which is really the main point of what
we want to make sure that we understand.

19
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:09.604
Microsoft does not officially
call them objective domains,

20
00:01:09.604 --> 00:01:13.050
right, in terms of what you and
I normally would see.

21
00:01:13.050 --> 00:01:16.280
They call them skills measured here.

22
00:01:16.280 --> 00:01:20.303
And then the skill measured, this is where
it becomes a little bit confusing because

23
00:01:20.303 --> 00:01:22.970
they have updated the exams skills.

24
00:01:22.970 --> 00:01:26.960
Normally, you do end up seeing these
four different domain objectives

25
00:01:26.960 --> 00:01:30.010
which will normally focus
in on each one of these.

26
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:33.330
Make sure that we do hit
every single detail in those

27
00:01:33.330 --> 00:01:36.550
as far as every domain
objective that they have.

28
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:40.580
But this last paragraph right before,
says as of June 2016,

29
00:01:40.580 --> 00:01:45.280
please download the change document.

30
00:01:45.280 --> 00:01:49.045
And that means that the details for
the exams have changed a little bit.

31
00:01:49.045 --> 00:01:50.987
They've taken some of
the older products out,

32
00:01:50.987 --> 00:01:54.250
some of the things that they really didn't
want to cover and also added them in.

33
00:01:54.250 --> 00:01:56.510
And they allow you to
see what has changed.

34
00:01:57.630 --> 00:02:01.440
I went ahead and downloaded this, and this
is what the document ends up looking like.

35
00:02:01.440 --> 00:02:03.615
So internally, they call them ODs or

36
00:02:03.615 --> 00:02:06.493
objective domains for
enabling the services and

37
00:02:06.493 --> 00:02:11.140
this is what will show you what skills
are actually going to be tested on, too.

38
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:14.412
Now you do wanna make sure that you
not only cover these as well, but

39
00:02:14.412 --> 00:02:16.640
make sure you have a good
working knowledge.

40
00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:20.710
So it really does give you the benefit,

41
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:23.360
if you've already been
working with Office itself.

42
00:02:23.360 --> 00:02:27.100
If you already had a little bit of
experience with Office 365, and of course,

43
00:02:27.100 --> 00:02:29.690
the networking side of that,
if you're connecting in.

44
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:34.120
So make sure you check out the 70-346
show before you go in and sit for

45
00:02:34.120 --> 00:02:35.540
this exam, too.

46
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:38.220
Take a look at some of the experience
that's required there,

47
00:02:38.220 --> 00:02:41.860
that they assume that you'll have
the knowledge for in this exam as well.

48
00:02:41.860 --> 00:02:42.900
When it comes down to it,

49
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:47.700
we'll be taking a look at the same
types of objective domains here.

50
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:51.989
We'll take a look at managing
the user driven deployments,

51
00:02:51.989 --> 00:02:57.050
as well as IT driven deployments
of Office 365 and Office 2016.

52
00:02:57.050 --> 00:02:59.715
We'll also set up telemetry and reporting,

53
00:02:59.715 --> 00:03:02.518
as well as talking about
the idea of planning for

54
00:03:02.518 --> 00:03:07.190
users to be able to get everything
working on their system as well.

55
00:03:07.190 --> 00:03:11.150
We'll also take a look of course,
at provisioning SharePoint Online

56
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:14.430
site collections to make them
work the way that we want to.

57
00:03:14.430 --> 00:03:16.210
And it's here beginning with the red.

58
00:03:16.210 --> 00:03:19.524
And some of the things that you see
crossed out and the red that's also

59
00:03:19.524 --> 00:03:24.360
replaced it, shows you the changes in the
domain objectives that have also happened.

60
00:03:24.360 --> 00:03:28.790
Along with this, there is a phrase that
you should pay attention to throughout

61
00:03:28.790 --> 00:03:34.210
the entirety of everything that you
study here for this particular exam.

62
00:03:34.210 --> 00:03:37.790
It's gonna be a phrase that repeats
over and over again where it says,

63
00:03:37.790 --> 00:03:41.260
using web UI and Windows PowerShell.

64
00:03:41.260 --> 00:03:46.690
You're not going to get away on this
exam without knowing the PowerShell.

65
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:50.420
Make sure you take time, study it,
make sure you're using it daily.

66
00:03:50.420 --> 00:03:53.710
That will help you out as you
also get ready for this exam.

67
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:56.010
They expect you to know
both not just one or

68
00:03:56.010 --> 00:03:58.610
the other,
make sure you pay attention there too.

69
00:04:00.110 --> 00:04:04.230
We'll also of course, take a look at
configuring Skype Online as well as Skype

70
00:04:04.230 --> 00:04:06.420
for Business for the end user settings.

71
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:08.230
And you'll see that we'll
go through each and

72
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:13.980
every one of these different objectives
within each smaller domain that we have.

73
00:04:13.980 --> 00:04:19.820
Lastly, of course, planning for Exchange
Online and Skype for Business too.

74
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:23.580
Where we will end up seeing of course,
multiple settings that we

75
00:04:23.580 --> 00:04:28.510
need to be able to make sure that we
understand and be able to configure.

76
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:30.755
All along this, this entire time,

77
00:04:30.755 --> 00:04:34.620
we will show you where you have
to be able to go into the web UI,

78
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:39.510
as well as the PowerShell to get things
configured to get ready for the exam.

79
00:04:39.510 --> 00:04:45.637
Now, if this is what you're looking for
in preparing for the Office 70-347 exam,

80
00:04:45.637 --> 00:04:50.310
well, you're in the right place
as we begin our journey together.

81
00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:53.740
And you'll take a look and you'll see
that there's plenty for us to do.

82
00:04:53.740 --> 00:04:56.833
So if you're ready for that,
make sure you stay tuned for

83
00:04:56.833 --> 00:04:58.709
the next episode coming right up.

84
00:04:58.709 --> 00:05:02.299
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss how to manage user-driven client deployments. They go back and forth examining the pros and cons of self- provisioning. Watch Ronnie explain how to configure restrictions as well.
episodes.title: Manage Clients Deployment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:06.020
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.020 --> 00:00:08.022
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.022 --> 00:00:12.241
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.241 --> 00:00:16.410
>> Welcome to your Enabling Office
365 Services series.

5
00:00:16.410 --> 00:00:18.630
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.630 --> 00:00:22.340
In this episode, we'll be looking at how
to manage your clients' deployments.

7
00:00:22.340 --> 00:00:24.900
And with us today, in studios,
we have Mr Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:24.900 --> 00:00:26.200
Thank you for joining us, Ronnie.

9
00:00:26.200 --> 00:00:30.190
>> Well, thank you for having me back,
as we take a look here at Office 365, and

10
00:00:30.190 --> 00:00:34.560
especially about,
of course, managing, well,

11
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:36.480
really, Office, right, Microsoft Office.

12
00:00:36.480 --> 00:00:41.260
2016 was installed on our computer,
but really Office 365 itself.

13
00:00:41.260 --> 00:00:44.590
Since we're really talking
about Office 365 services,

14
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:49.000
one of the key aspects of this, of course,
if you're an Office 365 administrator,

15
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:53.830
is to make sure that every user that needs
it is gonna be able to have Office 365, or

16
00:00:53.830 --> 00:00:59.610
I should say Office 2016,
installed on their individual computers.

17
00:00:59.610 --> 00:01:03.116
And at some point in the past,
have you been a traditional network

18
00:01:03.116 --> 00:01:06.450
administrator or systems administrator,
like I have been.

19
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:10.146
The idea of deployments and software
deployments tended to take a lot of

20
00:01:10.146 --> 00:01:12.733
time and
a whole bunch of other configurations and

21
00:01:12.733 --> 00:01:15.820
considerations that we
needed to actually take.

22
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:20.790
So, this is something that as we get
started in Office 365 and saying, hey,

23
00:01:20.790 --> 00:01:23.840
we wanna make sure that everybody
has access to Office at least.

24
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:28.080
That we need to consider the management of
it and the way that it's normally done.

25
00:01:28.080 --> 00:01:30.940
And so that's what we're actually gonna be
taking a look at it in this episode too.

26
00:01:30.940 --> 00:01:31.600
>> Sounds great,

27
00:01:31.600 --> 00:01:34.380
now Ronnie, I've worked as a network
administrator in the past as well.

28
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:37.530
And a lot of the times,
I almost seem kind of a control freak.

29
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:40.150
Because you really wanna make sure
that everything within your realm of

30
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:42.190
responsibility is well taken care of.

31
00:01:42.190 --> 00:01:46.991
So when we look at solutions, such as the
topics we're gonna be covering here, and

32
00:01:46.991 --> 00:01:50.230
we see untraditional methods
of software deployment.

33
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:51.700
Should this be a cause for

34
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:56.040
concern when it comes to us giving
up too much of that control?

35
00:01:56.040 --> 00:01:57.460
>> Well, that's the key, right,

36
00:01:57.460 --> 00:02:01.750
is that now that the world has kinda
moved into more of a hybrid approach,

37
00:02:01.750 --> 00:02:04.990
instead of just everything being
managed within a single network.

38
00:02:04.990 --> 00:02:07.780
Where we have a centralized
deployment share and

39
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:10.080
even centralized deployment management.

40
00:02:10.080 --> 00:02:14.890
With Office 365, we now have to consider
the idea of cloud deployment too.

41
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:19.530
And the way that this ends up working in
Office 365 is what ends up happening is

42
00:02:19.530 --> 00:02:23.912
that every user now that has
a subscription into your organization's

43
00:02:23.912 --> 00:02:29.550
Office 365 normally, also, of course, gets
access to Office itself, which is fine.

44
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:33.960
Except that when it comes up
on their first initial login,

45
00:02:33.960 --> 00:02:38.910
it's fairly easy on how they deploy that,
which is just simply clicking on a button.

46
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:43.160
And what Cherokee's mentioning to us and
telling us is, hey, we're no longer in

47
00:02:43.160 --> 00:02:48.560
control of that, and are we giving
up too much control if we do that?

48
00:02:48.560 --> 00:02:51.332
Because in the past,
the reason behind this, right,

49
00:02:51.332 --> 00:02:55.069
is because with our organization,
if we bought Office, you had to pay for

50
00:02:55.069 --> 00:02:57.080
a certain number of licenses, right?

51
00:02:57.080 --> 00:03:00.128
And so when we pay for
this certain number of licenses,

52
00:03:00.128 --> 00:03:02.796
it means that we don't
tend to just give it out.

53
00:03:02.796 --> 00:03:05.700
Just willy nilly-
>> Haphazardly.

54
00:03:05.700 --> 00:03:07.500
>> Yeah, we just kind of say,

55
00:03:07.500 --> 00:03:11.100
all right, we're gonna deploy it either
in an image or whatever it might be.

56
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:14.120
But we end up handling it,
we end up controlling it.

57
00:03:14.120 --> 00:03:17.436
And we end up testing it, you name it,
there's so many different things.

58
00:03:17.436 --> 00:03:18.898
But Office 365, and

59
00:03:18.898 --> 00:03:24.020
their deployment methodology really kind
of stems in two different directions.

60
00:03:24.020 --> 00:03:28.504
Either we can go user-based types of
deployment or user-driven deployments, or

61
00:03:28.504 --> 00:03:31.060
we can go to IT managed deployments.

62
00:03:31.060 --> 00:03:34.400
And the default setup,
of course, is user-driven.

63
00:03:34.400 --> 00:03:38.484
So when we start to take a look
then as an Office 365 admin,

64
00:03:38.484 --> 00:03:41.220
are we giving up control when we do that?

65
00:03:41.220 --> 00:03:44.225
Well, let's think about some of the things
that we're really giving up, Cherokee,

66
00:03:44.225 --> 00:03:45.800
when we start thinking about this idea.

67
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:50.520
So let's take for an example that
what we've had a lot of times,

68
00:03:50.520 --> 00:03:53.770
of course, is just a limited
number of activations, right?

69
00:03:53.770 --> 00:03:59.360
And in that limited number of activations,
things could go wrong very quickly.

70
00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:02.790
Even during testing,
if we accidentally set a switch wrong,

71
00:04:02.790 --> 00:04:05.120
we could activate all of
these different copies.

72
00:04:05.120 --> 00:04:08.170
And then when it came time to actually
deploy the software out there,

73
00:04:08.170 --> 00:04:09.410
we actually didn't have
enough activations.

74
00:04:09.410 --> 00:04:11.355
>> We've already chewed
through all of those keys.

75
00:04:11.355 --> 00:04:13.970
[LAUGH]
>> Yep, you actually ended up having that.

76
00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:17.270
Or the other aspect that ends up happening
is, let's say that we go ahead and

77
00:04:17.270 --> 00:04:21.700
we buy a volume license for so
many different users that we have.

78
00:04:21.700 --> 00:04:25.079
But it also comes up then that a user,
they say, look,

79
00:04:25.079 --> 00:04:29.280
I'm not only needed on my desktop
computer right here where I work.

80
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:32.638
But I now need it on the laptop,
so that as I travel,

81
00:04:32.638 --> 00:04:34.916
I need to have that same software.

82
00:04:34.916 --> 00:04:38.735
Well, all of a sudden, you might not
have accounted for enough licenses just

83
00:04:38.735 --> 00:04:42.760
when you think that you did, because you
provided at least to one for every user.

84
00:04:42.760 --> 00:04:46.670
So now, not only does that happen, but now
you're actually putting on two different

85
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:49.660
machines, and soon,
you're gonna run out of licenses again.

86
00:04:49.660 --> 00:04:52.600
The other thing that ends up running
out of licenses is fairly simple.

87
00:04:52.600 --> 00:04:57.130
Let's take for an example here that what
Cherokee does is that she says well,

88
00:04:57.130 --> 00:05:01.210
it'd not only be nice for
me to have it at the office here and

89
00:05:01.210 --> 00:05:03.350
on a laptop when I'm
actually out travelling.

90
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:08.040
But I know that if I had it on my home
computer, okay, then I would get so

91
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:09.660
much more work done.

92
00:05:09.660 --> 00:05:11.910
>> Because that's what
I wanna do everyday.

93
00:05:11.910 --> 00:05:14.610
>> Of course, yeah, but I mean,
things like this happen where-

94
00:05:14.610 --> 00:05:15.158
>> Sure, well,

95
00:05:15.158 --> 00:05:16.670
even with our mobile devices, right?

96
00:05:16.670 --> 00:05:19.040
We're able to install it
on our mobile devices and

97
00:05:19.040 --> 00:05:22.080
essentially become an around-the-clock,
an employee.

98
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:26.330
>> Yeah, and so when something like that
ends up happening where now you thought,

99
00:05:26.330 --> 00:05:30.070
well, maybe, two per user, and
all of a sudden, you're realizing three.

100
00:05:30.070 --> 00:05:32.710
Because if Cherokee asked,
somebody else is gonna ask us.

101
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:35.680
Cherokee's gonna say,
yeah, the IT department-

102
00:05:35.680 --> 00:05:38.192
>> Ronnie let me have five installs, yeah.

103
00:05:38.192 --> 00:05:39.206
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, why not?

104
00:05:39.206 --> 00:05:39.734
Why not?

105
00:05:39.734 --> 00:05:41.430
Let's just keep handing it out.

106
00:05:41.430 --> 00:05:45.440
And so what ended up happening then is,
of course, that would continue to go on.

107
00:05:45.440 --> 00:05:48.617
So when you start thinking about
what you're giving up here,

108
00:05:48.617 --> 00:05:52.910
well, a lot of that actually does kind of
get a little bit more concerning, right?

109
00:05:52.910 --> 00:05:57.840
But it all comes down to licensing and
managing the licensings that we also have.

110
00:05:57.840 --> 00:06:01.770
The key also, of course, is,
if we have it just as part of, for

111
00:06:01.770 --> 00:06:04.760
example, the image that we talked about,
right?

112
00:06:04.760 --> 00:06:07.820
The very fact is, I work for
an organization in which we image

113
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:11.840
the computers probably once a quarter, if
not even more often than that, depending

114
00:06:11.840 --> 00:06:15.970
on how much usage that we have, especially
in that training facility, right?

115
00:06:15.970 --> 00:06:19.870
Well, when you start doing that and now
the activations are just being depleted by

116
00:06:19.870 --> 00:06:23.720
one classroom, it becomes a little
bit more and more challenging.

117
00:06:23.720 --> 00:06:27.640
It's not that you can't go and
get those things turned around.

118
00:06:27.640 --> 00:06:30.565
But a lot of times,
if you actually ended up getting so

119
00:06:30.565 --> 00:06:35.180
many activations automatically, then you
had to manually start activating them.

120
00:06:35.180 --> 00:06:38.600
And that meant time on the phone,
listening to an automated message, and

121
00:06:38.600 --> 00:06:41.098
then having to go around
every computer to activate.

122
00:06:41.098 --> 00:06:45.753
So these automated type of things
can really run licenses very

123
00:06:45.753 --> 00:06:48.100
quickly out than we realized.

124
00:06:48.100 --> 00:06:52.250
And lastly, of course, is that if we
said all right, here you go, Cherokee.

125
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:53.750

that's exactly where you need to check it.

And I went in and switched our gears

It's a little bit more attractive.

And there you see it.

484

Here are the links for the Office mobile

00:27:36.850 --> 00:27:40.890

490

>> To download the Office apps that you
want for your phone or your tablet.

491
00:27:48.140 --> 00:27:52.680
So it gives me those options on which

492
00:27:52.680 --> 00:27:57.620
From that point if I select one,
let's see if I can select that one or.

00:27:57.620 --> 00:27:59.090
>> This is just so interesting Ronnie.

494
00:27:59.090 --> 00:28:03.620
If you think about phones in general,
and how they've kind of evolved.

495
00:28:03.620 --> 00:28:06.330
And how you are putting
PowerPoint on a mobile device.

496
00:28:06.330 --> 00:28:07.110
>> Yep, there it is.

497
00:28:07.110 --> 00:28:11.110
And you see what it really did is it
led me back to the Google Play store,

498
00:28:11.110 --> 00:28:12.110
is what it did.

499
00:28:12.110 --> 00:28:15.990
So it's simply a link, all those
links they aggregated together, and

00:28:15.990 --> 00:28:17.070
said here it is.

501
00:28:17.070 --> 00:28:21.339
So if somebody is not fairly familiar
with going into the Google Play store,

502
00:28:21.339 --> 00:28:24.554
but they can actually open up
the site on their computer.

503
00:28:24.554 --> 00:28:25.517
Well they can do that.

504
00:28:25.517 --> 00:28:28.070
And now I can click Open.

505
00:28:28.070 --> 00:28:31.180
And there we go on my phone it's
saying hey do you want to allow

00:28:31.180 --> 00:28:32.930
access to these things?

507
00:28:32.930 --> 00:28:37.780
Sure I'll allow access to those,

And there it goes setting it up for

00:28:41.720 --> 00:28:44.250
And it may ask me to register back in.

If it does so, we'll see.

Continue here.

Sure, why not?

And we'll see here for a moment,

Once again,

officeprodemoco.onmicrosoft.com.

I click Next, and it's connecting.

And now it's asking me for

So it's kind of like just

>> Right, so

So, it's connecting into the Office

00:29:44.320 --> 00:29:46.110

00:29:46.110 --> 00:29:49.160
And notice that they're

00:29:49.160 --> 00:29:52.050
even on my mobile device

528
00:29:52.050 --> 00:29:55.390
So you can see where

And if we now check, here's our last

Let's see if it actually changed

And if it does, it might take a moment or

00:30:10.040 --> 00:30:12.460
>> To reflect that we have now

>> Yep, it may, but it really doesn't.

00:30:15.430 --> 00:30:16.890
So you can actually see right there.

535
00:30:16.890 --> 00:30:20.780
There's nothing that's

536
00:30:21.830 --> 00:30:24.400
Everything is pretty much ready to go.

537
00:30:24.400 --> 00:30:27.830
I'm just clicking on the install

538
00:30:27.830 --> 00:30:30.580
And there it is still listed as two

539
00:30:30.580 --> 00:30:31.475
>> So it just might need

>> It's either a few minutes or

this is one of those mobile installs

>> Got you.

But that's something that at least get

the apps here.

Make sure you take a look,

547
00:30:45.550 --> 00:30:48.870
make sure you try and

Make sure you take a look around

00:30:52.270 --> 00:30:55.140
That's gonna be key for
your exam on deploying.

550
00:30:55.140 --> 00:30:58.350
My Office to your mobile devices too.

And, ladies and gentleman, thank you for

We're gonna take a look at how to manage

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Ronnie shift gears and examine the software management from an IT department management. They discuss the custom update options and learn how to streamline that process. They also take a look at the office deployment tool which allows the administrator to manage installations, configure update options and more!
episodes.title: Manage IT Office 365 Deployments
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.536
Welcome to ITPro.Tv,
I'm your host, Don Pezet-

2
00:00:03.536 --> 00:00:04.533
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.533 --> 00:00:07.890
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.890 --> 00:00:10.274
>> You're watching ITPro.Tv.

5
00:00:10.274 --> 00:00:15.680
>> Welcome to your enabling
Office 365 Services Series.

6
00:00:15.680 --> 00:00:17.770
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:20.510
In this episode,
we're kind of be shifting gears and

8
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:23.800
looking at our client deployments
from another perspective,

9
00:00:23.800 --> 00:00:27.260
we'll be looking at it from
an IT management side of things.

10
00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:30.435
And with us today we have Mister
Ronnie Long in studios, thank you for

11
00:00:30.435 --> 00:00:31.376
joining us Ronnie.

12
00:00:31.376 --> 00:00:35.497
>> Well thank you ver, having me back
here as we continue to take a look at

13
00:00:35.497 --> 00:00:40.190
this aspect of office deployment in the
very first couple of shows that we did or

14
00:00:40.190 --> 00:00:43.270
the first couple of episodes
that we took a look at.

15
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:45.190
We took a look at user driven deployments.

16
00:00:45.190 --> 00:00:48.360
And that's where the user is in control.

17
00:00:48.360 --> 00:00:51.080
We can still do some overall things,
right?

18
00:00:51.080 --> 00:00:55.730
Globally we can set it up to where we
can say hey don't install this and

19
00:00:55.730 --> 00:00:56.950
don't do this here.

20
00:00:56.950 --> 00:00:59.788
But now, taking it from the standpoint

21
00:00:59.788 --> 00:01:04.524
of a more traditional approach
where we can control everything.

22
00:01:04.524 --> 00:01:08.510
We can actually download
the deployment files itself.

23
00:01:08.510 --> 00:01:12.220
We can actually install it or
choose not to install it.

24
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:15.243
We can do all that.
We can even use group policy to help us to

25
00:01:15.243 --> 00:01:19.210
manage the way that the office
deployments can go.

26
00:01:19.210 --> 00:01:23.411
So, this is probably more familiar for
those of you that have been the network,

27
00:01:23.411 --> 00:01:26.562
the system admins that were in
control of this deployment.

28
00:01:26.562 --> 00:01:30.835
This is probably more of what people
really do think about when they think

29
00:01:30.835 --> 00:01:34.630
about controlling the idea
of deploying office here.

30
00:01:34.630 --> 00:01:38.280
So let's make sure that we
understand that with Office 365,

31
00:01:38.280 --> 00:01:42.710
some of the, different ways that
we can manage deployment and

32
00:01:42.710 --> 00:01:45.540
when it comes down theres
really three different options.

33
00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:47.040
We've already talked about one of them.

34
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:52.730
That user driven deployment where
essentially the user gets to download and

35
00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:57.537
directly install Office from
the Office365 Cloud itself.

36
00:01:57.537 --> 00:01:58.050
Right?

37
00:01:58.050 --> 00:01:59.650
When we start to take a look at that,

38
00:01:59.650 --> 00:02:04.980
the only thing that we really have
to ensure as the IT department side,

39
00:02:04.980 --> 00:02:09.990
right, is that the user understands his
limitation of the number of licenses that

40
00:02:09.990 --> 00:02:14.830
he's going to have access to, and what
happens when he over, when he says, hey,

41
00:02:14.830 --> 00:02:17.360
I need it on this many devices,
it's telling me I don't have enough.

42
00:02:17.360 --> 00:02:18.906
I still need it.

43
00:02:18.906 --> 00:02:21.701
You have to kinda let them know that,
hey, this is the limitation of this and

44
00:02:21.701 --> 00:02:23.110
that's all that there is going to be.

45
00:02:24.210 --> 00:02:28.320
You also may have to help the user
figure out where to download this from.

46
00:02:28.320 --> 00:02:32.830
This is normally not that difficult since
the majority of times they are going to

47
00:02:32.830 --> 00:02:36.970
have a button in the upper-right
hand corner that says install

48
00:02:36.970 --> 00:02:38.340
Office right here.

49
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:40.370
So, it shouldn't be that difficult.

50
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:41.580
But you never know.

51
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:43.660
An end user may get confused.

52
00:02:43.660 --> 00:02:47.030
So you may have to actually
let them know exactly

53
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:50.640
where to go to get that
particular download and install.

54
00:02:50.640 --> 00:02:52.810
So that is one of the ways.

55
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:56.080
But at least from the IT management point,
okay?

56
00:02:56.080 --> 00:03:00.820
We can limit, like I said, the global
installation features such as whether we

57
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:07.380
want them to install it at all, or whether
we want to manage that installment itself.

58
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:09.290
Now if we choose, look,

59
00:03:09.290 --> 00:03:11.450
what we're going to do is we're
not going to do it that way.

60
00:03:11.450 --> 00:03:13.800
We're not gonna allow
end users to install it.

61
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:15.180
Well then, you and

62
00:03:15.180 --> 00:03:20.740
I instead can download the installation
files to a central share from that

63
00:03:20.740 --> 00:03:26.360
point we can manage the installation
feature manually if we choose to.

64
00:03:26.360 --> 00:03:30.460
Now, this is a type that we're going to be
demonstrating in this particular series,

65
00:03:30.460 --> 00:03:34.460
because it actually takes the least
amount of setup for us to do for

66
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:36.390
the series that we're doing.

67
00:03:36.390 --> 00:03:39.450
But, there's a third option, and like I
said, we're gonna spend more time, so

68
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:43.170
that's why I'm not taking the time
to go into full description here.

69
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:47.550
But of course, the other option is if you
already have a current infrastructure

70
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:52.110
setup where you're using something like
system center configuration manager.

71
00:03:52.110 --> 00:03:55.700
You of course can use system
center configuration manager,

72
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:58.340
to do the deployment itself too.

73
00:03:58.340 --> 00:04:01.120
Now there's a particular tool
that we use called the ODT,

74
00:04:01.120 --> 00:04:02.960
that's what you'll normally hear it as.

75
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:05.000
Three letters O, D, and T.

76
00:04:05.000 --> 00:04:08.280
Stands for the Office Deployment Tool,
that will help you

77
00:04:08.280 --> 00:04:12.320
to at least get the installation files
to the central sharer that you want.

78
00:04:12.320 --> 00:04:16.540
And that's really that's kind of where the
commonality between the manual deployment

79
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:20.700
and using systems center comes in.

80
00:04:20.700 --> 00:04:22.810
But besides that though,
once you get that,

81
00:04:22.810 --> 00:04:25.650
then you follow all the instruction
inside the system center

82
00:04:25.650 --> 00:04:30.030
to manage your deployments throughout
your organization, wherever it might be.

83
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:32.000
With the manual deployment option though,

84
00:04:32.000 --> 00:04:34.780
it is downloading everything
to a centralized share, and

85
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:38.425
then requiring the running of,
well a couple of different commands.

86
00:04:38.425 --> 00:04:40.615
That we're going to be showing you too.

87
00:04:40.615 --> 00:04:41.450
Okay?

88
00:04:41.450 --> 00:04:46.260
So that is a part of the features that
we also have to think about, okay?

89
00:04:46.260 --> 00:04:49.160
So that's the one that we're
going to spend time on.

90
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:54.450
Now the other part of management that
we also have to think about of course

91
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:58.400
is going to be Office updates, okay?

92
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:03.890
Now, inside of Office365,
when we start talking about updates here,

93
00:05:03.890 --> 00:05:08.050
it does update differently
than the way that previous

94
00:05:08.050 --> 00:05:13.290
programs used to update before
the Office365 types of installation.

95
00:05:13.290 --> 00:05:18.760
And what I mean by that is, if you kind
of remembered in Office 2013 and in

96
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:24.060
previous editions, it really went through
the Windows Updating Service, right?

97
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:28.070
So, if you actually were connected and
you had automatic updates turned on,

98
00:05:28.070 --> 00:05:34.740
your Office products would also
follow the automatic update features.

99
00:05:34.740 --> 00:05:38.160
And would get updated in
that same fashion using,

100
00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:43.230
of course, the Windows updates or the
Windows Server Update services as well.

101
00:05:43.230 --> 00:05:47.836
And even the SECM to download and
do everything that we want it to.

102
00:05:47.836 --> 00:05:50.011
But with Office 365, though,

103
00:05:50.011 --> 00:05:54.664
it is a streaming update that when you
are connected to the Internet It will

104
00:05:54.664 --> 00:05:59.317
actually give us that ability to
download those updates directly without

105
00:05:59.317 --> 00:06:04.550
us having to worry about maintaining
an update service if we choose to.

106
00:06:04.550 --> 00:06:11.120
So, we have to consider that when we start
thinking about the idea of updating it.

107
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:14.100
The reason is that if you're
using Office 365 you probably

108
00:06:14.100 --> 00:06:18.740
downloaded the Office
365 Pro Plus edition.

109
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:21.520
And if you're in the Pro Plus
edition it means you're not going to

110
00:06:21.520 --> 00:06:23.880
get those updates through
automatic updates.

111
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:28.080
So you can't depend on automatic updates
to provide those if you need to.

112
00:06:28.080 --> 00:06:31.340
>> All right Ronnie,
if you're telling me that I can't depend

113
00:06:31.340 --> 00:06:35.360
on utilizing the Windows Update
process to obtain these updates,

114
00:06:35.360 --> 00:06:37.000
how do I go ahead and retrieve them?

115
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:41.340
>> Well,
this is where it becomes kind of fancy and

116
00:06:41.340 --> 00:06:43.720
tricky, but simple at the same time.

117
00:06:43.720 --> 00:06:47.630
And that's because they've tried to
automate everything to make it easier for

118
00:06:47.630 --> 00:06:50.830
the end user to begin to do this.

119
00:06:50.830 --> 00:06:56.050
So let me see if I can pull up a diagram
here to help us out, just a little bit.

120
00:06:56.050 --> 00:06:59.150
Here let me pull up the right diagram,
how is that?

121
00:06:59.150 --> 00:07:03.800
That would actually help quite a bit if
I actually pulled up the correct diagram

122
00:07:03.800 --> 00:07:07.220
to help us to take a look
at the management features.

123
00:07:07.220 --> 00:07:08.800
And what,
if it actually comes in there we go.

124
00:07:11.150 --> 00:07:13.490
And this will help us out too, all right.

125
00:07:14.670 --> 00:07:19.340
Now, the traditional deployment methods
that we've been talking about in the past,

126
00:07:19.340 --> 00:07:22.250
an individual user of course
has either deploy Office.

127
00:07:22.250 --> 00:07:26.680
They can do so idividually directly
from the Office 365 Portal.

128
00:07:26.680 --> 00:07:29.990
And that's pretty much the way
that we had been discussing

129
00:07:29.990 --> 00:07:33.230
the traditional of Deployments
all Office to do that.

130
00:07:33.230 --> 00:07:35.710
And that's a user driven Deployment right?

131
00:07:35.710 --> 00:07:39.370
They click on the link,

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at various options to manageclients updates as an administrator. First, Ronnie walks thru step to manually select update detaials such as what should be updated and how often. He also introduces the Office Deployment Tool (ODT) to help streamiline this process. In addition to using the default ODT settings, Ronnie also shows how to customize deployments via the ODT.

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee continue to use the ODT tool to specify how updates are obtained. Ronnie goes into detail with demonstrations to make sure this tool is understood. He shows how to set updates to the differed channel excluding unnecessary applications. They also explain the new Click to Run (C2R) method which helps streamline this update process.

00:17:41.277 --> 00:17:42.125
>> [LAUGH]
>> Overall though,

293
00:17:42.125 --> 00:17:45.369
in the way that that clicked to run,
and that's what you're looking for

294
00:17:45.369 --> 00:17:47.470
right here, is Click To Run, okay?

295
00:17:47.470 --> 00:17:51.710
Whenever you do something like that,
if anything is now finished installing,

296
00:17:51.710 --> 00:17:56.540
I should be able to see it over here,
yep and it will start populating it in.

297
00:17:56.540 --> 00:17:59.862
I know OneNote, I think, is there.

298
00:17:59.862 --> 00:18:02.640
But overall though,
it's not actually done.

299

So here, you won't actually see this, and

300
00:18:04.580 --> 00:18:09.050
it shouldn't take a long time since I
already had the download already on here

301
00:18:09.050 --> 00:18:12.680
but, it still takes just a few
minutes at least to run that.

302
00:18:12.680 --> 00:18:16.270
Now while we're doing this right,

303
00:18:16.270 --> 00:18:20.420
I want to show you the other one and

304
00:18:21.640 --> 00:18:25.320
Let me go back over here to where

305
00:18:25.320 --> 00:18:26.230
on this machine.

306
00:18:28.110 --> 00:18:30.626

307
00:18:30.626 --> 00:18:34.042
>> Now what you're actually looking at,
so here's kind of the file that we were

308
00:18:34.042 --> 00:18:36.409
using except the difference
here would be differed,

309
00:18:36.409 --> 00:18:38.720
I'm not gonna save this right now.

310
00:18:38.720 --> 00:18:43.180
Is here is the one that I run on
this machine a little bit earlier.

311
00:18:44.990 --> 00:18:48.642
So that this way we can
see that if I wanted to,

312
00:18:48.642 --> 00:18:53.320
I could actually limit what
gets on this computer.

313
00:18:53.320 --> 00:18:55.570
Now you might wonder,
why the heck do I want to do this?

314
00:18:55.570 --> 00:19:00.720
Remember not everybody might need access
to things like a Groove or Info Pack.

315
00:19:00.720 --> 00:19:01.820
I'm not saying they don't.

316
00:19:01.820 --> 00:19:05.360
But if you realize there's not
a lot of people using that.

317
00:19:05.360 --> 00:19:09.830
Well, now look at the way that
it's actually packaged here or

318
00:19:09.830 --> 00:19:13.430
the tag is says ExcludeApp.

319
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:15.670
So not only are we actually saying,

320
00:19:15.670 --> 00:19:20.010
here's the Product ID, right,
that we actually are downloading from.

321
00:19:20.010 --> 00:19:24.132
But we're saying, in that Product ID,

322
00:19:24.132 --> 00:19:30.930
when you do the configure,
exclude these apps right here, okay?

323
00:19:30.930 --> 00:19:35.414
And because, I don't know what every
single one is, there are times,

324
00:19:35.414 --> 00:19:38.778
the only one I know that's
missing right now because I

325
00:19:38.778 --> 00:19:39.514
chose it-
>> Excel?

326
00:19:39.514 --> 00:19:43.520
>> Is Excel,
which means it should install Excel, okay?

327
00:19:43.520 --> 00:19:44.951
So at least, that's the one that's there.

328
00:19:44.951 --> 00:19:49.454
But if I actually have forgotten one,
it will also end up installing as well.

329
00:19:49.454 --> 00:19:51.994
>> Okay.
>> And then, you can manually remove it,

330
00:19:51.994 --> 00:19:56.672
or if you want to you can add it back in
and make sure that excludes it again,

331
00:19:56.672 --> 00:19:58.870
if you wanna run through that.

332
00:19:58.870 --> 00:20:00.724
>> As long as you stick with
that proper syntax that they.

333
00:20:00.724 --> 00:20:01.480
>> Yep, yeah.

334
00:20:01.480 --> 00:20:04.480
As long as you stick with this,
you're pretty much ready to go.

335
00:20:04.480 --> 00:20:08.040
And so this one, it didn't take longer
than a couple of minutes to run.

336
00:20:08.040 --> 00:20:12.550
Excel got installed on this computer,
and it was off and ready to go.

337
00:20:12.550 --> 00:20:15.340
So you can see Excel there and, let's see.

338
00:20:15.340 --> 00:20:18.611
Let me see if I, I'm trying to see

339
00:20:18.611 --> 00:20:21.560
It looks like OneNote and
Outlook got installed again.

340

So I somehow missed that or

341
00:20:24.286 --> 00:20:26.314
>> Did you have them installed beforehand?

342
00:20:26.314 --> 00:20:28.070
>> I did have them installed beforehand.

343
00:20:28.070 --> 00:20:30.500
So it could have been that
it just left it behind.

344
00:20:30.500 --> 00:20:32.875
Not the overall program, but

345
00:20:32.875 --> 00:20:34.240
It could have left it behind.

346
00:20:34.240 --> 00:20:36.300
But here it's clearly excluded both.

347
00:20:36.300 --> 00:20:39.930
But I think those links

348
00:20:39.930 --> 00:20:41.620
But here,
we were actually able to do that.

349
00:20:41.620 --> 00:20:46.090
So not only can I manually control

350
00:20:46.090 --> 00:20:49.960
now I can actually run that and

351
00:20:49.960 --> 00:20:53.040
So I have that ability,
set it up, I'm trying to see,

00:20:53.040 --> 00:20:55.030
it looks like it's down to 3% here.

353
00:20:55.030 --> 00:20:57.850
And looks like the process
is starting to go down.

354
00:20:57.850 --> 00:21:02.200
So now we wanna verify and see,
if everything is almost done.

355
00:21:02.200 --> 00:21:05.840
Now I can tell that it's not

356
00:21:05.840 --> 00:21:10.760
because of what I told you here,
is that when I see that cursor come back

357
00:21:10.760 --> 00:21:15.620
to the actual prompt itself, just a y,
then I know it's completely done.

358
00:21:15.620 --> 00:21:16.770
Let's see if everything is.

359
00:21:18.110 --> 00:21:18.890
There it goes.

360
00:21:18.890 --> 00:21:21.560
Notice what's actually
getting added right now.

361

So these things just popped up.

362
00:21:23.010 --> 00:21:26.960
Word, PowerPoint, Outlook, Access.

363
00:21:26.960 --> 00:21:29.207
And this one says new right
here because earlier,

364
00:21:29.207 --> 00:21:31.507
when I was making sure that
this was working right,

365
00:21:31.507 --> 00:21:34.415
I had installed everything else,
but you see where it says new.

366
00:21:34.415 --> 00:21:37.900
So I'd run those programs a little bit
before, and so there's [INAUDIBLE].

367
00:21:37.900 --> 00:21:40.087
Look, Excel is brand new,
that's showing up now.

368
00:21:40.087 --> 00:21:41.343
>> That's what we were looking for.

369
00:21:41.343 --> 00:21:46.320
>> Yep, and these Office 2016 tools.

370
00:21:46.320 --> 00:21:51.300
So this is actually installing OneNote,
Outlook 2016,

371
00:21:51.300 --> 00:21:55.000
PowerPoint there, Skype for Business.

372
00:21:55.000 --> 00:21:57.300
It is doing the install, Word right here,

373
00:21:57.300 --> 00:22:01.040
all of that is actually brand
new to be able to do that.

374
00:22:01.040 --> 00:22:03.690
Now, once I select, let's say here, Word.

375
00:22:04.940 --> 00:22:09.500
I can run it, even though the install
process is not completely done.

376
00:22:09.500 --> 00:22:16.070
From this point, if I go to this
blank document, and I select File.

377
00:22:17.430 --> 00:22:20.060
And then Account,
over here on the left hand side.

378
00:22:24.340 --> 00:22:29.392
Notice right now were it says updates are
automatically downloaded and installed.

379
00:22:29.392 --> 00:22:32.600
This lets you know that this
is the current version.

380
00:22:32.600 --> 00:22:37.740
If it says differed, it actually said
differed here in terms of the updates.

381
00:22:37.740 --> 00:22:41.340
If you are not bound by
group policy to change this,

382
00:22:41.340 --> 00:22:44.770
you might see where you can actually
change these options here instead

383
00:22:44.770 --> 00:22:47.990
to disable or
view the updates or update now.

384
00:22:47.990 --> 00:22:52.740
So, those are possibilities
that you also end up seeing for

385
00:22:52.740 --> 00:22:56.650
everything else that you have to be
able to do here when you take a look.

386
00:22:58.090 --> 00:23:01.500
So it's still running at those
percentages, now it's down to zero.

387
00:23:01.500 --> 00:23:02.640
And that should be changing here.

388
00:23:03.960 --> 00:23:07.560
Now, the other thing that we also
have to think about, Cherokee,

389
00:23:07.560 --> 00:23:11.880
in our last few minutes here,
is to also think this idea and

390
00:23:11.880 --> 00:23:14.920
what about those computers
that are not domain joined?

391
00:23:14.920 --> 00:23:18.119
All right, that we really are,
it's saying, hey,

392
00:23:18.119 --> 00:23:20.190
this is gonna be on that computer.

393
00:23:20.190 --> 00:23:22.680
Can we still do the manual
updates this way?

394
00:23:22.680 --> 00:23:24.920
You can do it in the exact same way.

395
00:23:24.920 --> 00:23:28.250
You can go ahead and
install those as long as a person

396
00:23:28.250 --> 00:23:31.000
has their Office 365 account up and
ready to go.

397
00:23:31.000 --> 00:23:37.600
When you install it on those computers, it
should not join the domain, but you should

398
00:23:37.600 --> 00:23:41.250
see that once they're done, it might
ask them to log in for the first time.

399
00:23:41.250 --> 00:23:43.748
And once they do that,
you'll be able to do that as well.

400
00:23:43.748 --> 00:23:48.000
So that's really kind of the only
differences that you will end up seeing.

401
00:23:48.000 --> 00:23:51.152
Now that's the one file
I do want to show and

402
00:23:51.152 --> 00:23:54.926
also make sure of,
as we take a look at that folder.

403
00:23:54.926 --> 00:23:58.174
Let me go back in here and
see it's not completely done yet.

404
00:23:58.174 --> 00:24:00.806
But let me go back over here in that way,
so

405
00:24:00.806 --> 00:24:05.820
here was the other one I was gonna run,
but it's pretty much identical.

406
00:24:05.820 --> 00:24:07.460
>> Just to check your other install?

407
00:24:07.460 --> 00:24:12.590
>> Yep, so here when you take
a look at doing this deferred,

408
00:24:12.590 --> 00:24:16.970
notice here there is the channel
as far as the updates go.

409
00:24:16.970 --> 00:24:20.620
So first release deferred, okay.

410
00:24:20.620 --> 00:24:26.820
And that is something I definitely want
to point out as far as the syntax goes

411
00:24:26.820 --> 00:24:30.800
to get this thing right if you're gonna
do this through the configuration file.

412
00:24:30.800 --> 00:24:34.330
If you're changing this for testing for
releasing, this is something you

413
00:24:34.330 --> 00:24:38.720
definitely want to make sure that
you do have a clear grasp on.

414
00:24:38.720 --> 00:24:40.650
Remember that the other one is deferred,
and

415
00:24:40.650 --> 00:24:42.740
then the other one of course is channel.

416
00:24:42.740 --> 00:24:45.410
Those are kind of the key
ones that we really

417
00:24:45.410 --> 00:24:48.570
want to make sure that we
understand in the syntax.

418
00:24:48.570 --> 00:24:51.930
Review this syntax,
especially for this config file.

419
00:24:51.930 --> 00:24:54.170
It's really gonna help you out as well.

420
00:24:54.170 --> 00:24:58.630
So go back through, do a search in
your favorite search engine and

421
00:24:58.630 --> 00:25:03.490
type in configuration.XMLoptions and
you actually see that there's a whole

422
00:25:03.490 --> 00:25:07.830
list of them,
along with the product IDs for each one.

423
00:25:07.830 --> 00:25:11.210
But over here, on these update channels,
it's very important

424
00:25:11.210 --> 00:25:15.370
that we really take a note of those and
understand what those are all about.

425
00:25:15.370 --> 00:25:19.820
So once everything is done and finished,
that's what we'll do and of course then,

426
00:25:19.820 --> 00:25:22.162
if you had your testing group,
this is what you need.

427
00:25:22.162 --> 00:25:24.810
Going to your testing group and
you do the same thing.

428
00:25:24.810 --> 00:25:27.010
And you'll be off and ready to go as well.

429
00:25:27.010 --> 00:25:29.635
So it would just be a redundant
demo is what we would do.

430
00:25:29.635 --> 00:25:32.764
The only thing we would see different
is in that update that I showed you,

431
00:25:32.764 --> 00:25:35.254
it would just say, first release deferred-
>> Changing it, yep.

432
00:25:35.254 --> 00:25:35.958
>> That's all it would say.

433
00:25:35.958 --> 00:25:38.925
>> Just a little bit of change
of the syntax and, boy,

434
00:25:38.925 --> 00:25:40.860
that is pretty important there.

435
00:25:40.860 --> 00:25:43.030
We could even see that with
just a little bit of mistype.

436
00:25:43.030 --> 00:25:47.282
So at least you do have the additional
documentation to help you out if you

437
00:25:47.282 --> 00:25:50.010
forget those IDs and
just the overall syntax.

438
00:25:50.010 --> 00:25:52.660
So thank you Ronnie for
taking the time to demo that.

439
00:25:52.660 --> 00:25:56.002
But thank you ladies and gentlemen for
tuning in, and we're gonna go ahead and

440
00:25:56.002 --> 00:25:57.022
sign out for this show.

441
00:25:57.022 --> 00:25:59.600
I'm gonna sign out as
your host Cherokee Boose.

442
00:25:59.600 --> 00:26:01.920
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

443

[MUSIC]

444
00:26:08.866 --> 00:26:13.185

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Ronnie explain why and how one would use telemetry for reporting with Office 365.  They explain system requirements and other topics to consider prior to setting up the service.
episodes.title: Setup Telemetry and Reporting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.256
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.256 --> 00:00:06.070
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.070 --> 00:00:08.230
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.230 --> 00:00:12.027
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.027 --> 00:00:15.324
>> Welcome to your enabling
Office 365 Services series.

6
00:00:15.324 --> 00:00:17.136
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.136 --> 00:00:21.190
In this episode, we'll be looking
at telemetry and reporting.

8
00:00:21.190 --> 00:00:23.740
And with us today, in studio,
is we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:25.090
Thank you for joining us, Ronnie.

10
00:00:25.090 --> 00:00:28.460
>> Well, thank you for having me back
as we take a look at this aspect

11
00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:32.570
of telemetry which of course,
gives us a ton of data.

12
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:36.940
And then the reporting side of it so
that we can view the data, as well.

13
00:00:38.000 --> 00:00:41.410
And you might be wondering,
what in the world is going on here?

14
00:00:41.410 --> 00:00:43.560
Why do we really need something like this?

15
00:00:43.560 --> 00:00:44.950
Is kind of the key.

16
00:00:44.950 --> 00:00:46.880
When we start to do this.

17
00:00:46.880 --> 00:00:51.460
Telemetry can provide for organizations

18
00:00:51.460 --> 00:00:56.870
the data that they need especially
when they're choosing to upgrade or

19
00:00:56.870 --> 00:01:00.200
to migrate from maybe one
version of Office to another or

20
00:01:00.200 --> 00:01:04.400
maybe trying to migrate from something
different into Office as well.

21
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:09.660
And this is a key component of things
that we want to make sure that we can do.

22
00:01:09.660 --> 00:01:11.790
One of the hardest things right?

23
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:16.070
As your business continues to grow and
as you start to move in

24
00:01:16.070 --> 00:01:20.320
that direction where you just say hey,
I think we need to move to Office 365 or

25
00:01:20.320 --> 00:01:24.730
move to 2016 whatever version
you might actually move from.

26
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:28.390
The hard thing is to figure out
what actually needs attention

27
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:30.810
inside of your network a lot of times.

28
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:36.150
So the ability for us to say that we
can have something that monitors and

29
00:01:36.150 --> 00:01:41.570
spits information back to us from
our office users is gonna be key for

30
00:01:41.570 --> 00:01:43.810
us to be able to do this.

31
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:46.390
Now, we can do it in
a couple of ways right?

32
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:48.360
The manual way is fairly simple.

33
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:52.820
We go to all of our Office users, and
we simply, as the IT department would say,

34
00:01:52.820 --> 00:01:57.500
if you have any problems with Office at
all, please make sure you shoot us and

35
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:00.550
email and we'll try to take a look at it,

36
00:02:00.550 --> 00:02:04.420
and see if it's something
that we can take care of.

37
00:02:04.420 --> 00:02:05.800
And don't get me wrong,

38
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:09.030
that's actually a pretty solid
process if you want to do that.

39
00:02:09.030 --> 00:02:11.650
But the problem is,
it can be inconsistent.

40
00:02:11.650 --> 00:02:16.220
Even for one person, they might remember
at the very beginning to do so but

41
00:02:16.220 --> 00:02:18.840
then after a period of time,
they stop remembering.

42
00:02:18.840 --> 00:02:20.150
And they're still having the same issues.

43
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:24.280
They just go on, nothing's really being
resolved, so why even deal with it?

44
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:25.680
Or you have the other end extreme,

45
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:29.070
in which a person says I'm
not gonna worry about it.

46
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:30.770
If it doesn't work, it doesn't work.

47
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:33.170
And so
they never report to you the problems.

48
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:36.670
So in that sense,
it can actually go from those extremes.

49
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:40.330
So you get very uneven
amounts of data that come in.

50
00:02:40.330 --> 00:02:44.382
Especially when you're trying to go is
this worth us actually making the move to

51
00:02:44.382 --> 00:02:45.475
do things like that.

52
00:02:45.475 --> 00:02:52.420
Well, the great thing is, especially if
you're starting to run in Office 2016.

53
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:56.820
The Office telemetry data
is already there, okay?

54
00:02:56.820 --> 00:03:01.365
So in other words, in the background,
Office 2016 goes ahead and

55
00:03:01.365 --> 00:03:05.757
installs in everything to allow for
the telemetry data to be there,

56
00:03:05.757 --> 00:03:09.580
for us to be able to gather and
pull up as we need to.

57
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:14.100
Okay, so that's something that we really
want to make sure that we understand.

58
00:03:14.100 --> 00:03:17.980
And because once we actually can
determine what it is we need to monitor,

59
00:03:17.980 --> 00:03:20.530
it helps an organization to minimize risk.

60
00:03:20.530 --> 00:03:24.000
We might realize, we might not
be able to do what we want to.

61
00:03:24.000 --> 00:03:27.060
We might actually have to kind of
hold off on that a little bit more.

62
00:03:27.060 --> 00:03:31.191
It actually may give us that ability
to just take a little bit more time and

63
00:03:31.191 --> 00:03:33.660
understanding what we also see.

64
00:03:33.660 --> 00:03:39.080
The other thing of course that can help us
out with the idea of office telemetry is,

65
00:03:39.080 --> 00:03:44.860
even though we can monitor it a computer
at a time by going into event viewer and

66
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:47.820
looking at the logs on
every single computer.

67
00:03:47.820 --> 00:03:52.830
The telemetry or office telemetry
gives us the ability to collate and

68
00:03:52.830 --> 00:03:57.230
gather all that data and
have it report to a single location.

69
00:03:57.230 --> 00:03:59.280
And then using a single interface.

70
00:03:59.280 --> 00:04:02.180
We can pull all that data up and
see that, and

71
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:05.320
that way we can analyze it
across our entire domain.

72
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:06.950
>> Find any kind of correlations or

If I'm doing this for

So, make sure you understand that too.

And that's where you actually

episodes.description: Cherokee and Ronnie continue to explain to explain the telemetry reporting service. In this episode watch Ronnie demonstrate the set up and interface navigation. Learn how to enable this service via group policy and hack the registry for non-domain joined systems.

And Cherokee,

00:08:46.140 --> 00:08:49.570

00:08:49.570 --> 00:08:53.890

00:08:53.890 --> 00:08:57.160
past that four hour window if you
left it at the default setting there.

156
00:08:57.160 --> 00:08:57.900
>> That is correct.

00:08:57.900 --> 00:09:02.040
Yeah, you wouldn't actually get really
any good useful data within that point,

159

But if you're only willing to deal

00:09:07.830 --> 00:09:10.530

data it give you, that's fine.

But that's not always a complete picture,
so

But there are some other

And what you're looking for

That is the AgentInitWait, now you

Well, you can actually create this

00:10:16.890 --> 00:10:20.090
And that will insert these keys

00:10:20.090 --> 00:10:22.410
The key here is you can go and

00:10:22.410 --> 00:10:26.070
And you can actually find this,

And all you have to do is change the name

182

of where that common file
share is going to be.

183
00:10:31.860 --> 00:10:39.360
And then you can change this,
or you can leave it alone.

00:10:39.360 --> 00:10:42.500
So, in net weight.

Well, that's actually done I think

00:10:47.010 --> 00:10:48.270

And what the one indicates at least

Ronnie explains two methods of installing via Click-to-Run (C2R) and the older MSI method. They also look at different ways to deply updates. Specifically, Ronnie demonstrates how to use OffCAT.
episodes.title: Plan for Office Clients

WEBVTT

And a lot of the concepts that we

And it's just the order and

the skills measured on the exam.

And that's just way it came out.

So, logically it makes sense

But I just took the way that it came out,

So that's pretty much the only,

24

As far as,
if you're wondering why would he do that?

It's just because it-

26

The chicken or the egg here?

27

[LAUGH]
>> So but that's why.

Okay, so
if it is a little bit confusing, and

29

all of a sudden you've been
watching several episodes.

30

And you're like, he's kind of
reviewing a lot of stuff already,

31
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:32.060
what's going on here, and
that's because of that.

32

That's pretty much we gonna talk that.

33
00:01:33.600 --> 00:01:38.260
Now, when it comes out to the planning for
Office 365 clients, right?

34
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:43.190
What we are trying to do of
course is get them set up, and

35
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:48.050
understand the methodology of just
a little bit of that as we get started and

36
00:01:48.050 --> 00:01:50.500
what we actually have to begin to do.

37
00:01:50.500 --> 00:01:54.330
So, when it comes down to planning,
it really is about trying to say,

38
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:57.430
what do our clients really need,

39

to understand about the products that
we're about to show them or get to them.

40

And then making sure that they have a good
understanding of how to get what they need

41

to onto their machines and even do
a little bit of troubleshooting here.

42

So we're gonna see a little bit

We're also gonna talk about configuration

how easy that really is.

45

Also we'll end up seeing
a little bit more about

46
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:24.810
some of the other products that you might
not have actually been familiar with.

47
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:26.320
Skype for business, and lastly,

48
00:02:26.320 --> 00:02:31.180
we'll talk about troubleshooting Office
in it's installation on our machines too.

49
00:02:31.180 --> 00:02:33.920
So we'll actually see all
this in this episode, and

50
00:02:33.920 --> 00:02:35.600
that's what we're going to take a look at.

51
00:02:35.600 --> 00:02:37.930
>> Okay.
So Ronnie, I see here on our list,

52
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:39.100
we have C2R and MSI.

53
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:40.550
What are we talking about?

54
00:02:40.550 --> 00:02:42.950
Different ways to deploy
this installation?

55
00:02:42.950 --> 00:02:44.080
The very fact is,

56
00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:48.380
remember that when it comes down to
the way that we used to do software.

57
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:52.370
It was fairly simple, we either had
it on a DVD and we put in the DVD,

58
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:55.010
let the autorun take over and
we just simply clicked next.

59
00:02:55.010 --> 00:02:59.490
That's pretty much the way it
has been forever and a day.

60
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:01.270
Well now though and

61
00:03:01.270 --> 00:03:05.400
when you start doing stuff like that
as all of us have done in the past.

62
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:06.770
It was pretty much a waiting game, right?

63
00:03:06.770 --> 00:03:11.470
When we started to install software that
way, it took over your whole machine.

64
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:14.980
Its not like in the background you
could start playing something or

65
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:19.020
even start working on something else,
you essentially had to let the machine

66
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:20.520
kind of-
>> Run its course.

67
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:23.440
>> Run its course, and
then once it was done, we were done,

68
00:03:23.440 --> 00:03:26.070
and you know
>> Then we can actually move on to do

69
00:03:26.070 --> 00:03:27.150
other things.

70
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:32.310
But in today's world and the way that we
deploy software today is a lot different

71
00:03:32.310 --> 00:03:36.960
in the fact that Office 365
is a cloud solution for us.

72
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:42.160
We're no longer reliant on physical
media for the install anymore and

73
00:03:42.160 --> 00:03:47.060
even then when we actually do have it it
usually comes in the form of a download.

74
00:03:47.060 --> 00:03:49.090
When we start talking about
the idea of downloads,

75
00:03:49.090 --> 00:03:53.080
there is really two different ones for
installing office, okay?

76
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:57.680
The traditional way, especially
in a massive deployment solution,

77
00:03:57.680 --> 00:04:01.230
it might be using the dot MSI,
the Microsoft installer.

78
00:04:01.230 --> 00:04:06.030
That will allows us of course to use
some type of software policy, or

79
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:07.780
group policy, excuse me.

80
00:04:07.780 --> 00:04:09.260
To be able to run the install, and

81
00:04:09.260 --> 00:04:14.270
script it out, and allow then,
us to be able to configure it in that way.

82
00:04:14.270 --> 00:04:18.150
Set software restriction policies,
use AppLocker, do whatever we want to.

83
00:04:18.150 --> 00:04:20.330
The MSI is the way to go, okay?

84
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:22.990
So that's been traditionally
the way that we have installed

85
00:04:22.990 --> 00:04:24.440
products in the background.

86
00:04:24.440 --> 00:04:28.980
Gives us a lot of control
that we have available to us.

87
00:04:28.980 --> 00:04:33.230
But, if you think about it,
depends on what that stuff runs, right?

88
00:04:33.230 --> 00:04:36.540
So when we think about
the idea of group policy,

89
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:39.420
you've got to actually consider that,
right?

90
00:04:39.420 --> 00:04:41.460
When does group policy run?

91
00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:45.280
And that's kind of the key here, when we
start to understand, if we're gonna say

92
00:04:45.280 --> 00:04:49.370
hey, I think I do want to use something
like group policy to do the install.

93
00:04:49.370 --> 00:04:56.380
Or I can just download the MSI file to
a thumb drive of some sort right and

94
00:04:56.380 --> 00:05:00.640
then Cherokee can walk around to each
of the 700 machines that I have and

95
00:05:00.640 --> 00:05:06.010
install one yeah and one at a time making
sure that she has the product key,

96
00:05:06.010 --> 00:05:08.870
making sure that it follows
everything that we want to.

97
00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:11.059
But Cherokee, I would believe,
is smarter, and

98
00:05:11.059 --> 00:05:12.843
what she would do instead is [CROSSTALK].

99
00:05:12.843 --> 00:05:14.360
>> Work smarter, not harder, Rodney.

100
00:05:14.360 --> 00:05:16.190
>> Yeah, is to say, hey, look.

101
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:17.130
I think with an MSI we can.

102
00:05:17.130 --> 00:05:18.750
>> There's a more
efficient way to do that.

103
00:05:18.750 --> 00:05:20.140
>> Yeah,
there's gotta be a more efficient way,

104
00:05:20.140 --> 00:05:23.650
which is through Group Policy to do so,
okay?

105
00:05:23.650 --> 00:05:25.170
Even then.
So Cherokee,

106
00:05:25.170 --> 00:05:26.700
let's just talk about this for a moment.

107
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:28.050
>> Okay.
>> Group Policy.

108
00:05:28.050 --> 00:05:32.040
It tends to run, really, just a couple or
three different times, right?

109
00:05:32.040 --> 00:05:33.540
Somebody logs in.

110
00:05:33.540 --> 00:05:34.500
Somebody logs out.

111
00:05:34.500 --> 00:05:36.370
Okay?
Or when we reboot the machine.

112
00:05:36.370 --> 00:05:36.920
Yeah.
>> Force it.

113
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:37.540
>> Unforcing it.

114
00:05:37.540 --> 00:05:39.670
See you knew more than I did.

115
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:43.700
So at that point, right,
think about when that stuff runs.

116
00:05:43.700 --> 00:05:48.320
So let's say that we actually put a log
on script to run and install Office.

117
00:05:48.320 --> 00:05:54.300
Well, once we do that the process
logging in and then what happens?

118
00:05:54.300 --> 00:05:57.980
Now all of a sudden the script takes over,
and now we're installing Office.

119
00:05:57.980 --> 00:06:00.700
Unless they were installing
every product in Office now.

120
00:06:00.700 --> 00:06:03.620
Access, Excel, Word, Powerpoint.

121
00:06:03.620 --> 00:06:04.520
You name it.

122
00:06:04.520 --> 00:06:07.240
That could take several minutes at least,
right?

123
00:06:07.240 --> 00:06:07.900
>> Sure.

124
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:12.260
>> So even then as the person logs on,
it might actually do what?

125
00:06:12.260 --> 00:06:15.780
It might literally take a while
before they can use the machine.

126
00:06:15.780 --> 00:06:18.710
So it's not really a lot
different from the physical media,

127
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:21.070
except that Cherokee doesn't
have to walk around with it.

128
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:23.540
But overall though,
that's a lot easier on her, but

129
00:06:23.540 --> 00:06:26.950
the end user's still sitting there going,
I wonder when this is going to get done.

130
00:06:26.950 --> 00:06:30.610
>> I've got a deadline for
my report that's due in 15 minutes, and

131
00:06:30.610 --> 00:06:32.020
>> Good luck with that one.

132
00:06:32.020 --> 00:06:34.720
Yeah, because it's still going
to update after that, so

133
00:06:34.720 --> 00:06:37.670
you will have have issues
like that that go on.

134
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:39.080
So, that is a way.

135
00:06:39.080 --> 00:06:42.880
Okay so, that is a legitimate way
that we would have thought about but

136
00:06:42.880 --> 00:06:45.250
we did move super efficiently, right.

137
00:06:45.250 --> 00:06:48.410
One thumb drive, maybe ten thumb drives,
still has go around,

138
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:50.780
we still actually deploy everything too.

139
00:06:50.780 --> 00:06:52.640
But that's one way we can do it.

140
00:06:52.640 --> 00:06:58.930
Today the prevalent technology is C2R,
C, the number 2, and the letter R.

141
00:06:58.930 --> 00:07:02.620
That's an abbreviation for Click 2 Run.

142
00:07:02.620 --> 00:07:06.400
Now, Click 2 Run type
of download technology,

143
00:07:06.400 --> 00:07:11.780
it's not super different from the MSI as
far as downloading it and then running it.

144
00:07:11.780 --> 00:07:15.710
It says Click 2 Run, so it has to be
clicked somewhere to actually run it, so

145
00:07:15.710 --> 00:07:17.250
something has to trigger it.

146
00:07:17.250 --> 00:07:21.130
But the difference here though
is that now we can go directly

147
00:07:22.330 --> 00:07:28.350
to the Office 365 cloud and we simply just
click on a link inside of our subscription

148
00:07:28.350 --> 00:07:34.180
and that begins the process to download
that type of click to run file.

149
00:07:34.180 --> 00:07:38.720
The advantage of the click to run is not
in its ability to install Office like

150
00:07:38.720 --> 00:07:39.870
the MSI.

151
00:07:39.870 --> 00:07:45.570
But is ability to install office
in a streaming type of install.

152
00:07:45.570 --> 00:07:51.300
And what we mean there by doing this
is kind of a strange concept for me but

153
00:07:51.300 --> 00:07:57.903
it sends me concept right because it asses
like here is how big the Office suite is.

154
00:07:57.903 --> 00:08:00.960
But here's what we'll do,
Ronnie and Cherokee.

155
00:08:00.960 --> 00:08:05.260
Is that you can go ahead and
start downloading those files,

156
00:08:05.260 --> 00:08:08.750
I can start installing those files.

157
00:08:08.750 --> 00:08:13.580
And at the same time once that first
portion of the install is done you can go

158
00:08:13.580 --> 00:08:19.890
ahead and use that particular program
while I install in the background.

159
00:08:19.890 --> 00:08:21.100
Does that sound neater?

160
00:08:21.100 --> 00:08:24.610
>> Yeah, I think so,
I'm able to still work on my reports and

161
00:08:24.610 --> 00:08:27.210
I'm getting my new piece of software.

162
00:08:27.210 --> 00:08:28.750
So it's a win, win.

163
00:08:28.750 --> 00:08:32.990
>> It really is, it allows you to be
able to understand that process and

164
00:08:32.990 --> 00:08:36.340
to do a lot better in
terms of the install.

165
00:08:36.340 --> 00:08:39.070
And most users can handle that.

166
00:08:39.070 --> 00:08:42.890
We may not, okay, because I always still
have that issue because that's what I want

167
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:45.890
is, say, look, leave it alone.

168
00:08:45.890 --> 00:08:48.150
Don't mess with it while it's installing.

169
00:08:48.150 --> 00:08:51.780
But the click to run is designed
to do that streaming process

170
00:08:51.780 --> 00:08:53.980
to be able to do exactly that, okay?

171
00:08:53.980 --> 00:08:58.430
So that you can run it even though it's
actually in the middle of installing for

172
00:08:58.430 --> 00:08:59.890
another program.

173
00:08:59.890 --> 00:09:05.200
So, it's a neat thing and we did end
up seeing this in part of an install

174
00:09:05.200 --> 00:09:09.480
that we did earlier in a manual deployment
install, it allowed us to do this.

175
00:09:09.480 --> 00:09:12.720
Decision makers need to go ahead and
figure out

176
00:09:12.720 --> 00:09:17.710
what they actually want to happen and how
they choose for this to happen, as well.

177
00:09:17.710 --> 00:09:20.240
So if you are going to
use that click to run,

178
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:23.800
well, you can do it in
a user-driven type of deployment.

179
00:09:23.800 --> 00:09:28.420
Remember, this is allowing, of course, the
user to simply click on the install link

180
00:09:28.420 --> 00:09:31.000
and let it run, and let it install Office.

181
00:09:31.000 --> 00:09:35.350
And it will tell you, you can continue to
use your computer while this is going on.

182
00:09:35.350 --> 00:09:37.200
And then it will actually
fully install Office.

183
00:09:37.200 --> 00:09:40.490
But you can also end up using
the Office products within it too.

184
00:09:40.490 --> 00:09:41.210
The other thing,

185
00:09:41.210 --> 00:09:45.170
of course, is that once they actually
choose that, that's usually the way to go.

186
00:09:45.170 --> 00:09:50.040
But, if we want the IT managed type
of install, it can be done that way.

187
00:09:50.040 --> 00:09:54.380
We just disallow,
we kind of hide that button that allows

188
00:09:54.380 --> 00:09:59.500
the user to click and install itself.

189
00:09:59.500 --> 00:10:03.820
And instead we can use that
Office Deployment Tool that's out there

190
00:10:03.820 --> 00:10:05.910
that now we can download that.

191
00:10:05.910 --> 00:10:10.450
Run that along with the configuration.xml
file to customize and

192
00:10:10.450 --> 00:10:14.940
to control the setup the way
that we want to if we choose to.

193
00:10:14.940 --> 00:10:18.560
So that's kind of a reminder
of using both of these.

194
00:10:18.560 --> 00:10:21.730
But decision makers really
do need to understand

195
00:10:21.730 --> 00:10:26.680
that part of the process as we
start to take a look here, okay?

196
00:10:26.680 --> 00:10:28.640
So that is really the beginning.

197
00:10:28.640 --> 00:10:32.710
Now I had mentioned something a little
bit earlier where we were talking about

198
00:10:32.710 --> 00:10:37.270
the idea of, now that we have this,
a lot of time with the MSI,

199
00:10:37.270 --> 00:10:40.700
though, we still run
into some issues here.

200
00:10:40.700 --> 00:10:43.000
And it has to do with
the idea of updating,

201
00:10:43.000 --> 00:10:45.180
is what ends up happening here, okay?

202
00:10:45.180 --> 00:10:50.270
So, we've got to actually figure out here,
with the end of MSI, when we download this

203
00:10:50.270 --> 00:10:56.870
thing, and we do that, you don't know
how old the MSI really is, okay?

204
00:10:56.870 --> 00:10:59.210
It could actually be several months old,

205
00:10:59.210 --> 00:11:01.820
in terms of the process
of things going on.

206
00:11:01.820 --> 00:11:06.220
So if we download that MSI,
it might be from six months ago.

207
00:11:06.220 --> 00:11:08.020
It's very possible, okay?

208
00:11:08.020 --> 00:11:09.160
Or it could be from two months ago.

209
00:11:09.160 --> 00:11:12.340
Or it could be from eight months ago,
we don't really know.

210
00:11:12.340 --> 00:11:16.460
And that now means that after an MSI
gets installed on a computer,

211
00:11:16.460 --> 00:11:20.930
you normally do have to run
the updating of that product,

212
00:11:20.930 --> 00:11:25.690
which normally comes through
the automatic updates to do so.

213
00:11:25.690 --> 00:11:29.330
But that means it's more time that
you're waiting, after the updates end up

214
00:11:29.330 --> 00:11:33.610
happening, after everything else is
going on that's what goes on, okay?

215
00:11:33.610 --> 00:11:37.390
So that's where you have to kind of
pay attention at that point too.

216
00:11:37.390 --> 00:11:41.990
So when you're actually doing this,
that MSI may be the way that you choose

217
00:11:41.990 --> 00:11:45.960
to control it, but it means that you
do have to worry about updating.

218
00:11:45.960 --> 00:11:51.830
The click to run, though, the C2R,
it normally when you download it from

219
00:11:51.830 --> 00:11:56.300
the distribution network on
Office 365 on the cloud up there.

220
00:11:56.300 --> 00:11:58.020
>> You're getting the most
up to date information,

221
00:11:58.020 --> 00:12:01.990
you don't have to worry
of that stale version.

222
00:12:01.990 --> 00:12:07.030
>> Yeah, exactly, the very fact is
in the click to run modeling or

223
00:12:07.030 --> 00:12:11.090
what we wanna call it there, there are
particular way of deferring those channels

224
00:12:11.090 --> 00:12:13.960
that they do the updates here.

225
00:12:13.960 --> 00:12:18.960
Is that you're never actually going to

phones, you name it.

00:24:52.260 --> 00:24:56.440

00:26:12.955 --> 00:26:15.742

00:26:53.630 --> 00:26:54.930

00:26:54.930 --> 00:26:58.090

00:26:58.090 --> 00:27:01.314

that should actually

I was trying to remember why that

It actually did end up getting installed.

00:27:38.990 --> 00:27:41.330
So that's one of the things

Installing one product is actually

So using something like that is really

518
00:28:24.270 --> 00:28:29.948

00:28:29.948 --> 00:28:32.585

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie plan out what clients will need to be able to connect to Office 365 for the Office Products they will need access to.  They mention the different licenses available and the assignment of those licenses are based on what the user will need to be able to do.  According to the team, so users will use only web based access like Office Online; others may need to download and install Office 2016, all this is done before any assignment and during the planning stage.  They also show the Office Configuration Analyzer tool to help out with post planning effectiveness too.
episodes.title: Plan for Office Clients Part 2

Additional security verification,

some particular applications, Outlook,

00:14:29.020 --> 00:14:33.990
But since mine worked I'm

There's all the e-mails and

00:14:40.124 --> 00:14:43.421
Joey's account that has been set up and

00:14:43.421 --> 00:14:47.490
So we can actually get people to do

It didn't really take much,

00:14:48.871 --> 00:14:51.756

00:14:59.440 --> 00:15:04.430
Now what if your actually

00:15:07.830 --> 00:15:11.590
And that makes it easier but

you might not be able to say,

00:15:16.140 --> 00:15:17.917
You might be able to say that, but

a lot of times it's really up to

00:15:21.483 --> 00:15:25.815
But normally providing at least one or two

Is kind of the key there,

cuz normally I have that at all times

00:15:37.508 --> 00:15:41.751
But here you have a very simple basic to

275
00:15:56.370 --> 00:16:00.924
Usually the other thing might end up being

password, and typos are usually

But besides that, there it is,

00:16:06.536 --> 00:16:10.830
you've seen now that not only that

00:16:10.830 --> 00:16:15.620
But now we've also set it up to where

00:16:15.620 --> 00:16:20.350
side is actually easy to set up, and

281
00:16:20.350 --> 00:16:23.630
at the same time it does require

282
00:16:23.630 --> 00:16:27.945
But once they actually get it set up, it

having a simple email address and
password to get connected in.

284
00:16:31.384 --> 00:16:36.070
>> Yeah, you're kind of underplaying
that Ronnie, a bit more security.

285
00:16:36.070 --> 00:16:36.950
But think about it.

286
00:16:36.950 --> 00:16:40.021
I mean, we really are adding
that additional layer so

from that amount of work that you just
completed that you guys just saw.

288
00:16:44.130 --> 00:16:48.320
Think about having to basically you're
making more work for the attacker.

289
00:16:48.320 --> 00:16:51.870
And they're not just going to be able to
utilize one particular program to perform

290
00:16:51.870 --> 00:16:54.070
a brute force attack or
something like that.

291
00:16:54.070 --> 00:16:58.410
So, it's definitely worth looking into
if you have the ability to go ahead and
