293
00:17:00.600 --> 00:17:02.110
>> At least it's an early warning for

294
00:17:02.110 --> 00:17:06.280
you if somebody does try to hack
into your own, like Office.

295
00:17:06.280 --> 00:17:10.230
If I left my computer open and they were
able to get access to my computer and

296
00:17:10.230 --> 00:17:13.600
they launched Office,
it's asking them to authenticate,

297
00:17:13.600 --> 00:17:16.610
well if I have my phone on me,
I know that somebody's trying to do it.

298
00:17:16.610 --> 00:17:19.710
And if I'm not expecting it,
that may actually give me a red flag,

299
00:17:19.710 --> 00:17:23.360
at least an early warning that something
like this is beginning to happen.

300
00:17:23.360 --> 00:17:27.934
But just kinda realize that that's

301
00:17:27.934 --> 00:17:31.834
So either using that phone or
using the app password method, either one

302
00:17:31.834 --> 00:17:36.170

303
00:17:36.170 --> 00:17:39.220
So, that is pretty much what I wanted

that we saw is not just only the setup,

But for this show, we will sign out.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie take look at Office 365 update changes.  They discuss the terminology changes and what is the purpose and target of each update channel.  They also discuss the basic update methodology used with Office 365 ProPlus
episodes.title: Create a Pilot Group for Testing Updates
episodes.transcript:

1
00:00:00.058 --> 00:00:02.621
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.621 --> 00:00:06.634
>> [CROSSTALK]

3

In this episode, we'll be taking

Because we've talked about our

So as we started to take a look at the

And so we're reshooting, or we're actually

And this particular topic is

So we wanted to make sure that you

And that includes, of course, this idea

And specifically the Office 2016

79
00:04:13.197 --> 00:04:17.890
You see them happening kind of random and

80
00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:22.694
So, when we're looking at our

What are some essentials that we really

>> Well, the easiest way, of course,

Which is Microsoft's website,

86

So, let's take a look at my computer here,

88
00:04:41.753 --> 00:04:46.635
Overview of update channels for
Office 365 ProPlus.

89
00:04:46.635 --> 00:04:50.352
So this is the edition that you get your
Office 365 subscription up and running.

90
00:04:50.352 --> 00:04:52.802
When you install it on your computers,

00:04:52.802 --> 00:04:57.505

92

Now back when we first started

the way that they updated, they were

94
00:05:04.929 --> 00:05:08.030
And let me scroll down,

95
00:05:08.030 --> 00:05:09.655
Let me scroll down here, and

00:05:09.655 --> 00:05:13.869

Prior to September 2017, these update

98
00:05:20.256 --> 00:05:25.120

99
00:05:25.120 --> 00:05:26.677
Not exactly the easiest or

00:05:26.677 --> 00:05:30.508
most intuitive naming convention

00:05:30.508 --> 00:05:32.884
But that's what they actually
have them call them,

103
00:05:35.950 --> 00:05:37.836
But now with this update,
what we're telling you is,

104
00:05:37.836 --> 00:05:38.663
that's changed.
>> And

105
00:05:38.663 --> 00:05:41.830
I actually like the new names

00:05:41.830 --> 00:05:45.418
Especially if you're an avid shopper and

00:05:45.418 --> 00:05:47.858

108
00:05:47.858 --> 00:05:48.718
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

00:05:48.718 --> 00:05:53.650
there's no doubt, so over on the kind

00:05:53.650 --> 00:05:57.242
You'll see right up here at the top,

111
00:05:57.242 --> 00:06:01.950
Well, they've changed those names to match
with what we call a Monthly Channel.

112

And then Semi-Annual Channel.

113
00:06:03.970 --> 00:06:08.598
And then, of course,
they really didn't diverge too far,

114
00:06:08.598 --> 00:06:11.255
Semi-Annual Channel Targeted.

115
00:06:11.255 --> 00:06:15.338
So, Semi-Annual Channel Targeted.
>> [LAUGH]

116
00:06:15.338 --> 00:06:16.589
>> All of these kind of relate in this.

117
00:06:16.589 --> 00:06:17.178
>> That's a mouthful.

118
00:06:17.178 --> 00:06:17.871
>> Yeah, it is a mouthful.

119
00:06:17.871 --> 00:06:18.747
>> Yeah, but you just think

120
00:06:18.747 --> 00:06:19.672

121
00:06:19.672 --> 00:06:21.606
You've got your semi-annual sales, so

00:06:21.606 --> 00:06:23.491

123
00:06:23.491 --> 00:06:24.312
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

124
00:06:24.312 --> 00:06:25.145
>> You and I do shopping a lot

125
00:06:25.145 --> 00:06:26.421
differently.
>> [LAUGH]

126
00:06:26.421 --> 00:06:28.603
>> [LAUGH] And what I would actually do,

00:06:28.603 --> 00:06:30.930
but overall though, it works for us,

128
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:31.732

>> Sure.

129
00:06:31.732 --> 00:06:32.288
>> So, the way

130
00:06:32.288 --> 00:06:33.910
that the Monthly Channel does it.

131
00:06:33.910 --> 00:06:37.091
It coincides with what was
referred to earlier in our series,

132
00:06:37.091 --> 00:06:38.999
what we called the Current Channel.

133
00:06:38.999 --> 00:06:43.856
The Semi-Annual Channel that you're

134
00:06:43.856 --> 00:06:47.180

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie take look at Office 365 update changes.  They discuss the terminology changes and what is the purpose and target of each update channel.  They also discuss the basic update methodology used with Office 365 ProPlus.
episodes.title: Create a Pilot Group for Testing Updates Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie explain how to configure external SharePoint users. They demonstrate how to set up sites and apply access restrictions to comply with various access control models. Tune in to learn how to implement this concept via the GUI and PowerShell.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discuss how to set up configure external SharePoint users access. First, Ronnie demonstrates how to restrict or allow access via the GUI. He also warns and shows how a slight configuration can be quite involved to reverse. They also show how to use the PowerShell commandlet, Set-SPOSite -Identity to configure from a CLI.
episodes.title: Configure External SharePoint Users Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue their demonstration on adding external SharePoint users. They use the "Share link" option to invite an external user. They also demonstrate how to remove external user access using the web UI and Windows PowerShell.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie discuss SharePoint site collection. The breakdown resource quotas and how it is different from a storage quota. They then configure a resource quota through the use of PowerShell.
episodes.title: Create SharePoint Site Collection

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie explain the collaboration concept and begin explaining an internal social media platform called Yammer. Ronnie demonstrates how to enable and use yammer to increase an organizations communication.

589
00:32:01.450 --> 00:32:03.450
people always ask questions like,
do I lose any information?

590
00:32:03.450 --> 00:32:04.310
You don't.

591
00:32:04.310 --> 00:32:07.580
You don't lose any information,
once you turn it off, but

592
00:32:07.580 --> 00:32:10.400
at the same time,
it will keep it in the background.

593
00:32:10.400 --> 00:32:13.540
But it does take about a half
hour to actually turn on and

594
00:32:13.540 --> 00:32:15.078
to do more if you're doing this.

595
00:32:15.078 --> 00:32:16.310
So be careful.

596
00:32:16.310 --> 00:32:19.280
>> What are the big differences
between the SharePoint

597
00:32:19.280 --> 00:32:23.160
news feed versus the Yammer, I mean, why
would I choose to use one or the other?

598
00:32:23.160 --> 00:32:26.550
>> Remember that news feed is just
going to be exactly what we have

599
00:32:26.550 --> 00:32:28.770
inside of the news reader.

600
00:32:28.770 --> 00:32:31.910
It shows data as it's coming across,
but it doesn't give you

601
00:32:31.910 --> 00:32:37.200
the conversational feature that you would
have in live time communication and that.

602
00:32:37.200 --> 00:32:41.610
You can still have the collaboration
where you share and where you can modify,

603
00:32:41.610 --> 00:32:44.155
and edit documents, and
create them, co-owner.

604
00:32:44.155 --> 00:32:47.190
Co-author them, you name it and
you can still do that.

605
00:32:47.190 --> 00:32:52.540
But with Yammer though, you actually add
in that kind of communication feature,

606
00:32:52.540 --> 00:32:53.550
is what you're doing.

607
00:32:53.550 --> 00:32:57.330
To make it more alive and
to make it more social media like instead.

608
00:32:57.330 --> 00:32:59.360
Is what you have the ability to do.

609
00:32:59.360 --> 00:33:01.930
So Yammer itself, it is a good product.

610
00:33:01.930 --> 00:33:03.330
If you begin with it.

611
00:33:03.330 --> 00:33:07.230
But if you don't begin with it, right,
it means the buy-in is very important for

612
00:33:07.230 --> 00:33:08.250
your company.

613
00:33:08.250 --> 00:33:09.950
But at least those things, right?

614
00:33:09.950 --> 00:33:13.340
Make sure you know where to turn on
this Enterprise Social Collaboration.

615
00:33:13.340 --> 00:33:16.060
And understand that if
you're gonna create a group,

616
00:33:16.060 --> 00:33:20.470
you'll probably have to be an admin to
create the group to do what you want to.

617
00:33:20.470 --> 00:33:24.950
And then, from that point all you do is
you invite members and they are off and

618
00:33:24.950 --> 00:33:25.720
they are ready to go, but

619
00:33:25.720 --> 00:33:28.900
if they are gonna be using Yammer,
this has to be enabled for

620
00:33:28.900 --> 00:33:32.210
them to do so, if they're not, well
then you don't have to worry about it.

621
00:33:32.210 --> 00:33:33.880
Well, it still show up in Yammer, yes, but

622
00:33:33.880 --> 00:33:37.660
not everybody will actually end up using
as their main feature, because this

623
00:33:37.660 --> 00:33:41.530
watch as you turn it on, so only a few
where invited in Yammer when we use it.

624
00:33:41.530 --> 00:33:45.832
But here if you want this to become
the default, that's what you have to do.

625
00:33:45.832 --> 00:33:49.460
>> All right Ronnie, we are just about out
of time for this episode but weve really

626
00:33:49.460 --> 00:33:53.925
just scraped the surface of the different
collaboration tool we have available.

627
00:33:53.925 --> 00:33:57.405
So thank you for joining us and thank you,
ladies and gentlemen, for joining as well.

628
00:33:57.405 --> 00:33:59.985
But stay tuned because we have
more information headed your way.

629
00:33:59.985 --> 00:34:01.615
Let me go ahead and sign out.

630
00:34:01.615 --> 00:34:03.445
As your host, remember,
I'm Cherokee Boose.

631
00:34:03.445 --> 00:34:04.255
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

632
00:34:04.255 --> 00:34:06.055
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

633
00:34:06.055 --> 00:34:13.603
[MUSIC]

634
00:34:13.603 --> 00:34:18.820
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to examine collaboration tools. First, the explain what co-authoring is and different ways it can be implemented. They also explain what office 365 groups are and how it would benefit an organization.
episodes.title: Plan a Collaboration Solution Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.713
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.713 --> 00:00:06.515
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.515 --> 00:00:08.305
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.305 --> 00:00:13.030
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.
>> Welcome to your

5
00:00:13.030 --> 00:00:15.450
enabling Office 365 series.

6
00:00:15.450 --> 00:00:17.720
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.720 --> 00:00:20.960
In the previous episode we really
spent a lot of time focusing on

8
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:23.260
Yammer which is a collaboration tool.

9
00:00:23.260 --> 00:00:28.100
In this show, we'll look at and
explore additional collaboration tools.

10
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:31.040
And with us today, back in the studios,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:31.040 --> 00:00:32.210
Thank you for joining us, Ronnie.

12
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:33.560
>> Well, thank you for having me back,

13
00:00:33.560 --> 00:00:37.670
as we take a look at more of these
different ways that we can collaborate.

14
00:00:37.670 --> 00:00:42.184
>> So Ronnie, what is the first tool
that we'll be looking at in this show?

15
00:00:42.184 --> 00:00:47.610
>> Well, when it comes down to what
we really need to look at right now,

16
00:00:47.610 --> 00:00:52.600
is the ability to do the idea of editing,
of authoring.

17
00:00:52.600 --> 00:00:55.150
But instead of just one person authoring,

18
00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:57.300
we're now talking about multiple
people being able to do it,

19
00:00:57.300 --> 00:01:00.830
we'll call co-authoring is what
we're taking a look at here.

20
00:01:00.830 --> 00:01:05.170
So, when we start to do that we
have to understand that particular

21
00:01:05.170 --> 00:01:06.880
concept as well.

22
00:01:06.880 --> 00:01:10.600
So, in the previous episode I mentioned
that one of the ways we tend to do

23
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:13.269
collaboration without all
these tools is simple.

24
00:01:13.269 --> 00:01:17.331
We might just have a file share and
from that point, I might edit it,

25
00:01:17.331 --> 00:01:19.753
but you might also be able to edit it, but

26
00:01:19.753 --> 00:01:23.350
only if you actually kind of
take advantage of that to do so.

27
00:01:23.350 --> 00:01:25.250
And then, when you try to put it back,

28
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:27.800
it will end up creating a duplicate
file of what we normally see.

29
00:01:27.800 --> 00:01:31.420
>> Now, when you hear that term,
co-authoring, I can assume that it

30
00:01:31.420 --> 00:01:36.070
means more than one author or owner, but I
don't wanna go ahead and assume anything.

31
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:37.950
So, can you expand on
that a little bit and

32
00:01:37.950 --> 00:01:40.610
let me know if there's anything I
should know about co-authoring?

33
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:45.750
>> It really is about that
idea of being able to make

34
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:49.620
that document have essentially
two owners to the document.

35
00:01:49.620 --> 00:01:54.720
But at the same time, also be able to edit
the document instead of one at a time,

36
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:57.830
so it's not asynchronous
here where I write.

37
00:01:57.830 --> 00:02:01.270
Cherokee edits it then, I go and
read the revisions here.

38
00:02:01.270 --> 00:02:04.010
I disagree with a revision and
I send it back to Cherokee.

39
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:07.180
Cherokee makes the edit or
changes it back or whatever it is.

40
00:02:07.180 --> 00:02:10.350
And then, I go and
change something else and

41
00:02:10.350 --> 00:02:13.070
then, Cherokee reviews it and
comes back here.

42
00:02:13.070 --> 00:02:16.960
But it gives us the chance,
depending on how we have it set up

43
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:22.240
to where we might be working on
the document exactly at the same time,

44
00:02:22.240 --> 00:02:26.860
which does kind of bring up,
it's gotta be some conflicts, right?

45
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:30.530
So, for example, if all of a sudden
Cherokee and I spot the exact same work

46
00:02:30.530 --> 00:02:34.370
and this is hypothetical, of course,
in let's say a Word document.

47
00:02:34.370 --> 00:02:38.890
And she decides to change it to this Word
and I decide to change it to that Word,

48
00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:42.990
well, which one at that point actually
takes over and takes precedent,

49
00:02:42.990 --> 00:02:44.990
is what we're really talking about here.

50
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:48.260
And that's where it becomes a little bit
harder, depending on what we're doing.

51
00:02:48.260 --> 00:02:52.930
The great thing about doing something
like co-authoring is that as Cherokee

52
00:02:52.930 --> 00:02:57.120
marks what she wants to change and
what normally ends up happening here,

53
00:02:57.120 --> 00:03:00.350
is that I can actually see where
she might be deleting a word, and

54
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:01.940
it actually has her name beside it.

55
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:05.360
And that way I go, I better not mess with
that right now, let me go ahead and take

56
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:09.450
a look, or she might delete out a sentence
and actually retype a new sentence in.

57
00:03:09.450 --> 00:03:13.100
And that let's me know that she
is working on the document too.

58
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:15.930
So, in terms of co-authoring,
there's really

59
00:03:15.930 --> 00:03:20.260
two different types of co-authoring
that we're really interested in.

60
00:03:20.260 --> 00:03:24.257
And one of them is what we
call regular co-authoring.

61
00:03:24.257 --> 00:03:29.740
Regular co-authoring, it's going to sound
a little bit strange, but here is the key.

62
00:03:29.740 --> 00:03:33.620
Regular co-authoring allows us
both to connect to the document

63
00:03:33.620 --> 00:03:38.230
that's normally stored on
a shared folder location, okay?

64
00:03:38.230 --> 00:03:40.460
For us, that would be One Drive or

65
00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:43.030
SharePoint collection,
whatever it might be.

66
00:03:44.150 --> 00:03:47.660
And we both can connect to
that at the very same time.

67
00:03:47.660 --> 00:03:51.720
We both can actually provide
edits at the same time, but

68
00:03:51.720 --> 00:03:57.240
the actual edits are only
seen when you hit save.

69
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:01.000
So, that's where it becomes a little bit
tricky, we both have to be doing that.

70
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:03.410
So, it allows for simultaneous changes,

71
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:08.100
which I'm not gonna be able to say,
to the document with other people.

72
00:04:08.100 --> 00:04:10.510
But the changes are only seen

73
00:04:10.510 --> 00:04:14.760
when somebody presses Save
at that particular point.

74
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:18.050
So, now a new save, what that should do

75
00:04:18.050 --> 00:04:22.900
on the other end as they see it wow it
says hey, look, updates are now available.

76
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:27.610
So, it might be where Cherokee, how she
edited the first part of the document, and

77
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:29.270
I don't see any of those changes.

78
00:04:29.270 --> 00:04:30.320
And then, she hit Saved and

79
00:04:30.320 --> 00:04:33.840
all of a sudden I get a notification
that updates are available.

80
00:04:33.840 --> 00:04:36.730
And from that point, I should see and
refresh the document and

81
00:04:36.730 --> 00:04:39.340
that should actually give me
the changes that Cherokee made.

82
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:40.490
>> All right, Ryan.

83
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:44.160
What if I was on a conference call
with you and a couple other people and

84
00:04:44.160 --> 00:04:47.220
I wanted to edit that document
collaboratively in real-time?

85
00:04:47.220 --> 00:04:48.520
Is there an option for that?

86
00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:49.320
>> There really is.

87
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:52.432
And that is exactly what they
call real-time co-authoring, and

88
00:04:52.432 --> 00:04:54.219
that actually makes sense for us too.

89
00:04:54.219 --> 00:04:58.584
So, when we do real time co-authoring,
I again just like I was describing

90
00:04:58.584 --> 00:05:01.495
a little bit earlier,
it gets media ability to see

91
00:05:01.495 --> 00:05:07.090
Cherokee make the changes at the same time
as I might be working on the document too.

92
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:12.110
So, the great advantage of this probably
isn't something like we're working on

93
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:17.520
let's say a streamline process like a
story, but as far as just a regular story.

94
00:05:17.520 --> 00:05:20.080
But you can see where
this might be helpful for

95
00:05:20.080 --> 00:05:22.100
certain people like developers, right?

96
00:05:22.100 --> 00:05:26.170
That are actually taking a look at
the code, and seeing the code as they work

97
00:05:26.170 --> 00:05:29.820
through it and being able to see
that single-wherever they coded that

98
00:05:29.820 --> 00:05:33.370
information into to make the changes
that they need to at the same time.

99
00:05:33.370 --> 00:05:35.610
It might be a real helpful solution for

100
00:05:35.610 --> 00:05:38.510
them if they were doing
something like this as well.

101
00:05:38.510 --> 00:05:42.210
So, those two are pretty much
the key when you do this.

102
00:05:42.210 --> 00:05:46.040
Now, you do have decide on which
ones are actually the better fit for

103
00:05:46.040 --> 00:05:49.690
your company when you choose
to do something like that.

104
00:05:49.690 --> 00:05:55.010
And that's a little bit harder that goes
beyong the scope of just talking about it.

105
00:05:55.010 --> 00:05:59.160
That's when you have the plan and
say which one is the better fit for us?

106
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:02.580
Real time editing can happen, okay?

107
00:06:02.580 --> 00:06:08.410
But it can lead to some unusual conflicts
instead of actually revealing changes and

108
00:06:08.410 --> 00:06:10.540
then, making changes, okay?

109
00:06:10.540 --> 00:06:13.250
That's probably more of
an editorial process,

110
00:06:13.250 --> 00:06:16.300
whereas real time live coauthoring.

111
00:06:16.300 --> 00:06:18.150
If you were in the same room,

112
00:06:18.150 --> 00:06:21.070
it will probably lead to some
fist fights at times, right?

113
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:22.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> But-

114
00:06:22.170 --> 00:06:23.830
>> No, it has to say this, or

115
00:06:23.830 --> 00:06:25.430
it has to say that, exactly.

116
00:06:25.430 --> 00:06:29.560
>> Yeah, so you do, you have to kind of
plan that out to what your organization

117
00:06:29.560 --> 00:06:31.590
needs best if you're doing this.

118
00:06:31.590 --> 00:06:35.110
By default, though, SharePoint,
I want to make sure I say this right.

119
00:06:35.110 --> 00:06:38.990
One Drive and
SharePoint have this turned on by default.

120
00:06:38.990 --> 00:06:43.650
So if you have your documents
in one drive and now,

121
00:06:43.650 --> 00:06:47.500
you're saying I need to make sure that
somebody else is involved in this and

122
00:06:47.500 --> 00:06:50.900
being with co-authoring to this,
all you have to do is share this out and

123
00:06:50.900 --> 00:06:53.540
give them the privileges
that they need to do so, and

124
00:06:53.540 --> 00:06:57.950
that will allow for
the a co-authoring test to occur.

125
00:06:57.950 --> 00:07:00.340
So, let's see if we can actually
make an example of this.

126
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:03.690
If everything is actually set
up the way that it should be,

127
00:07:03.690 --> 00:07:06.700
we should be able to do this,
but let's check it out here.

128
00:07:06.700 --> 00:07:10.240
So, we'll go ahead and
take a look at my machine.

129
00:07:10.240 --> 00:07:13.250
>> Ronnie, are there any kind of system
requirement to prove requisites that we

130
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:14.046
should be aware of?

131
00:07:14.046 --> 00:07:16.170
I know that you said that it is enabled,
but

132
00:07:16.170 --> 00:07:19.315
anything additional that
I need to know about?

133
00:07:19.315 --> 00:07:22.705
>> Not really, right, because most of
the time that we're doing this inside

134
00:07:22.705 --> 00:07:27.645
of the portal,
we're just connecting to their machine and

135
00:07:27.645 --> 00:07:30.430
we're not downloading it
to our machine to do this.

136
00:07:30.430 --> 00:07:34.480
We can, but if we're only using
even like the Office online tools,

137
00:07:34.480 --> 00:07:38.330
it doesn't take a lot for
us to do anyways.

138
00:07:38.330 --> 00:07:41.310
So, let's go ahead and find,
we'll create a document here.

139
00:07:41.310 --> 00:07:45.950
I'm going to click on the Word online
tool for us and select this one.

140
00:07:45.950 --> 00:07:47.809
This new blank document here.

141
00:07:51.186 --> 00:07:54.887
And once I get this document,

142
00:07:54.887 --> 00:08:01.114
this is a test of the emergency
broadcast system.

143
00:08:05.009 --> 00:08:07.320
This is only a test.

144
00:08:07.320 --> 00:08:09.690
>> [LAUGH] I'm glad.

145
00:08:09.690 --> 00:08:12.880
>> All right so now, everything is there.

146
00:08:12.880 --> 00:08:14.580
Let me save this.

147
00:08:16.660 --> 00:08:21.110
And I'm gonna save a copy online for
right now and we'll call this test.

148
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:25.204
One, test one.

149
00:08:28.489 --> 00:08:33.627
All right now, while I have this
document saved, notice in the upper

150
00:08:33.627 --> 00:08:38.870
right hand corner there's this big
blue button here that says Share.

151
00:08:38.870 --> 00:08:41.180
Let me see if I can zoom in, all right.

152
00:08:42.280 --> 00:08:48.700
Select Share, and this is where we get
the chance to actually say what we can do.

153
00:08:48.700 --> 00:08:51.850
The key is also over here
on the right hand side.

154
00:08:51.850 --> 00:08:55.050
We can invite certain people if
we want to, but it's whether or

155
00:08:55.050 --> 00:08:58.500
not they can edit or
they can only view is the key.

156
00:08:58.500 --> 00:09:00.560
If I want co-authoring to occur,

157
00:09:00.560 --> 00:09:04.600
I need to make sure that they
can edit the document instead.

158
00:09:04.600 --> 00:09:06.540
So I have that option.

159
00:09:06.540 --> 00:09:10.490
I can also select this,
Get a link, instead and

160
00:09:10.490 --> 00:09:13.830
this actually is a little bit
different when we do this.

161
00:09:13.830 --> 00:09:18.629
Notice that if I select, Get a link,
Edit link, no sign-in required

162
00:09:18.629 --> 00:09:23.120
means as long as the person has the link,
they can do whatever they want to.

163
00:09:23.120 --> 00:09:26.310
You also note that you
can do a Restricted link.

164
00:09:26.310 --> 00:09:30.370
View a link here,
which says these accounts are required.

165
00:09:30.370 --> 00:09:36.170
Notice that these are internal accounts
here on the View link and Edit link.

166
00:09:36.170 --> 00:09:41.160
And then View link, no sign-in required
and Edit link no sign-in required.

167
00:09:41.160 --> 00:09:43.570
And this is the one that was just created.

168
00:09:43.570 --> 00:09:47.740
So I can limit the access in
this way if I choose to, but for

169
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:48.950
right now I'm not gonna worry about it.

170
00:09:48.950 --> 00:09:53.340
I'm gonna actually choose
the Invited here, okay.

171
00:09:53.340 --> 00:09:56.800
The other thing of course is to make sure
that when you actually have it shared

172
00:09:58.400 --> 00:10:02.280
that you have stored this into
either your own OneDrive, or

173
00:10:02.280 --> 00:10:05.500
the OneDrive for business, or
your SharePoint site, okay.

174
00:10:05.500 --> 00:10:07.368
And once you have that
then you're ready to go.

175
00:10:07.368 --> 00:10:14.133
So let me share this
one with Lance here and

176
00:10:14.133 --> 00:10:20.329

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Ronnie continue to discus the myriad of collaboration tools available in Office 365. They begin by explaining how to use OneDrive for Business to simplify sharing documents. They also explain how to migrate preexisting files to OneDrive for Business. Lastly, Ronnie expounds on how Office 365 video can be a useful tool.
episodes.title: Plan a Collaboration Solution Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at Delve which is a cloud based collaboration software. Here they show you how to access, setup, and work with Delve. Also discussed is Data Loss Prevention(DLP) as it is implemented in Office365.

And now, look at that,

>> I know I am.

But as for this episode we

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their collaboration solution by configuring Data Loss Prevention(DLP) services in Office365. Here they will take you through each of the steps, detailing each, to get DLP enabled for your environment.
episodes.title: Plan a Collaboration Solution Part 5

As well as now turning to

Use data loss prevention

The other thing about the data loss

Especially on the data losses and

Every company, especially big companies,

You can start from a custom,

that's It's almost like trying to reinvent

00:07:52.649 --> 00:07:56.396
They've gone ahead and they've tried to

138
00:07:59.420 --> 00:08:02.350
So you're wondering,

Notice they give us a major category.

Financial information, Medical and health,

Privacy, those are kind of the three big

144
00:08:16.270 --> 00:08:19.100
Let's select Financial,

145
00:08:19.100 --> 00:08:22.140
Depending on where you are in the world,

146
00:08:22.140 --> 00:08:24.430
Notice that we have

00:08:24.430 --> 00:08:29.340
And let's just select that one just as

00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:33.900

149
00:08:35.670 --> 00:08:38.870
And now as I scroll in,

helps detect the presence of
information commonly considered

00:08:41.610 --> 00:08:47.340

152
00:08:47.340 --> 00:08:51.850

153
00:08:51.850 --> 00:08:53.810
this is really good.

154
00:08:53.810 --> 00:08:55.860
What if I'm here in the United States and

155
00:08:55.860 --> 00:09:01.260
I'm actually in charge of setting this but

00:09:01.260 --> 00:09:04.900
It wouldn't be great for

157
00:09:04.900 --> 00:09:06.390
But I can actually set it and

158
00:09:06.390 --> 00:09:10.070
notice that these are actually by
country which is very good for us.

159
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:11.241
But let's say for

160
00:09:11.241 --> 00:09:16.471
example that we know that our company is
supposed to follow the PCI DSS, right,

161
00:09:16.471 --> 00:09:21.952
that payment card industry data security
standard that is available out here too.

162
00:09:21.952 --> 00:09:26.617
Helps detect the presence of information
subject to the PCI Data Security Standard,

163
00:09:26.617 --> 00:09:30.116
including information like credit card and
debit numbers, and

164
00:09:30.116 --> 00:09:33.970
it shows you what those numbers
are protecting as well.

165
00:09:33.970 --> 00:09:36.890
And as we scroll down,
you can see a few of them.

166
00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:41.010
So as I scroll through here,
you actually notice it's not only based on

167
00:09:41.010 --> 00:09:44.540
country because that's the way laws
are and regulations normally are,

168
00:09:44.540 --> 00:09:46.160
especially on financial data.

169
00:09:46.160 --> 00:09:49.060
Here is the US financial
data where we are located

170
00:09:49.060 --> 00:09:51.929
right here in
the United States in Florida.

171
00:09:52.950 --> 00:09:55.940
Credit card numbers,
US bank account numbers, the ABA,

172
00:09:55.940 --> 00:09:59.690
American Business Association routing
numbers, that are also there.

173
00:09:59.690 --> 00:10:03.784
If you're doing trade,
right, stock market stuff,

174
00:10:03.784 --> 00:10:08.480
notice they have that,
US Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act.

175
00:10:08.480 --> 00:10:12.070
So they even have some of the more
common and up to date ones.

176
00:10:12.070 --> 00:10:15.080
This one, of course,
includes in your federal ID

177
00:10:15.080 --> 00:10:19.650
number as well as your social security
number to get everything in there.

178
00:10:19.650 --> 00:10:22.980
So all of this information
is a nice little template,

179
00:10:22.980 --> 00:10:28.970
at least at the beginning, that you and
I can use to set some financial data

180
00:10:28.970 --> 00:10:33.300
if we want to, and see what we want to
block from ever getting out of my company.

181
00:10:33.300 --> 00:10:38.730
If I'm in the healthcare industry or
in the fields that support that,

182
00:10:38.730 --> 00:10:42.980
notice once again we have different acts

00:25:36.790 --> 00:25:41.410
us to actually deal with than what we have
time for in the remainder of this episode.

479

So we're actually, probably gonna

I know Mike's surprised that I

481

But overall though [LAUGH] he's
laughing like crazy, are you joking me?

482

That's a norm-
>> Can you see the shocked look

484

>> [LAUGH] Really?

>> No way.
>> Is that possible?

486

>> No, we love it Ronnie,

cuz you've got all this information that

So, so far we've seen why

And we've created the site

Where are we gonna pull the information

But as Ronnie said
there's a lot more to it.

494
00:26:18.490 --> 00:26:20.140
We still got to work on permissions.

495
00:26:20.140 --> 00:26:23.491
I'm assuming Ronnie, both permissions

496

and gather all those emails from

497

We're gonna be reaching into
multiple user's emails.

498

So who has permission to do that?

499
00:26:31.650 --> 00:26:34.240
And then once that
information is gathered,

500

we probably need to control
who can access that.

501
00:26:36.275 --> 00:26:38.340
>> Right.
>> I just can't have just Joe Anybody

502
00:26:38.340 --> 00:26:41.250
reading through everybody's emails,
or accessing that information.

503
00:26:41.250 --> 00:26:44.710
So we've got a lot more to do
to configure the eDiscovery.

504
00:26:44.710 --> 00:26:47.010
So we appreciate you hanging
out with us Ronnie, and

505

showing those great demonstrations,
and coming back for part three.

506
00:26:50.680 --> 00:26:54.000
So that we can continue on
with setting up eDiscovery.

507
00:26:54.000 --> 00:26:55.370
But for now we are out of time.

508
00:26:55.370 --> 00:26:58.620
So signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

509
00:26:58.620 --> 00:26:59.370
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

510
00:26:59.370 --> 00:27:01.671
>> And we'll see you next time.

511
00:27:01.671 --> 00:27:08.436
[MUSIC]

512
00:27:08.436 --> 00:27:14.800
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue setting up an eDiscovery site in SharePoint. They demonstrate creating a security group to control access to the eDiscovery site. They show how to do this using the GUI as well as with PowerPoint. They also add memberrs to the group.
episodes.title: Configure eDiscovery Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.395
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don.

2
00:00:02.395 --> 00:00:08.225
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.225 --> 00:00:09.554
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:09.554 --> 00:00:12.205
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.205 --> 00:00:15.435
>> Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.435 --> 00:00:17.430
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick and

7

today we're doing our

8

And specifically in this episode,

9

We've got it kind of set up, right, we've

But now we're gonna go back and do some

00:00:44.671 --> 00:00:48.590
And here to help us out with that of

15

Welcome back Ronnie.

16

>> Well thank you for
having me back on the show,

17
00:00:51.570 --> 00:00:56.450
as we continue on to take a look at this
very important topic of eDiscovery, and

18
00:00:56.450 --> 00:01:01.190
making sure that we're configuring it to

As we do so, we've already set up, like

We even showed you last time how to

we can population the information inside

But now we've got this issue that

Which is now that we've got that set up,
well, who's gonna be issuing the commands?

25
00:01:24.250 --> 00:01:28.225
Who's actually going to be doing these
things that we need to gather all that

information in?

And that comes down to now adding,

That really have the permissions that they

To be able to do all

30

There's a couple of different

31

And it's something that we

We had only really
configured one source for

the results that we want

And we did tell you that you can
go of course and set this up for

00:02:03.621 --> 00:02:06.980
SharePoint as well as for
OneDrive for Business.

00:02:06.980 --> 00:02:10.230
And getting all those different
services where it can search throughout

00:02:10.230 --> 00:02:13.400

And that way we can get everything we want

00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:19.935
if you want to you set it up for

00:02:19.935 --> 00:02:23.330
But, remember that when we start to

different permission or users to do this,
we wanna be smart about it as well.

44
00:02:28.520 --> 00:02:30.000
And that's why we wanna

45

and I'm gonna see if Mike can figure

46

And Mike's probably like,

But this way I'm hoping,

I'm hoping that you'll also

So, let's show you how to do this,

really do it inside the Power Shell, cuz

But you at least need to know both

But it is heavily tested in PowerShell.

So let's take a look here.

I am logged in as the site or

essentially which is

Because something in eDiscovery,

is that the people that are managing

There's only one or two possibilities,

So a single user, they can be the ones
that are the administrators and

65
00:03:38.092 --> 00:03:40.497
of course the owners to a particular site.

66
00:03:40.497 --> 00:03:42.413
That means they can do
anything that they want to and

00:03:42.413 --> 00:03:45.690

But the other thing that can happen
though is that we can set up

00:03:50.047 --> 00:03:52.023

And that way,
whoever we assign to that security group,

72

Now Mike, why would it,

cuz Mike's an Active Directory expert

74
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:09.510
Mike why is it better to create
a group instead of just saying,

75
00:04:09.510 --> 00:04:11.228
why don't we put Joey on everything?

76
00:04:11.228 --> 00:04:14.421
>> One of the problems that you're
gonna run into if you assign it to

77
00:04:14.421 --> 00:04:17.510
an individual user is,
when it comes time to change, right?

78
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:20.390
What if that person no longer
needs those permissions or right?

79
00:04:20.390 --> 00:04:23.240
I've gotta manually undo all of that.

80
00:04:23.240 --> 00:04:26.200
Whereas if I use a group to
assign the permissions to,

81
00:04:26.200 --> 00:04:29.150
even if it's just one person,
I can now put that one person in there.

82
00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:32.670
Because tomorrow, a month from now,
a year from now, you might have two or

83
00:04:32.670 --> 00:04:35.300
three people that need those provisions or
ten people and

84
00:04:35.300 --> 00:04:36.880
I don't have to give
an assignment to each one.

85
00:04:36.880 --> 00:04:39.350
I can simply add them to the group and
we're good to go.

86
00:04:39.350 --> 00:04:42.955
And if Joey leaves the organization or
changes roles and

87
00:04:42.955 --> 00:04:47.263
no longer should have access to
that eDiscovery site collection.

88
00:04:47.263 --> 00:04:50.200
Then I can just pull him out of the group
and he no longer has those permissions.

89
00:04:50.200 --> 00:04:52.946
I don't have to go back and double
check and undo access control lists and

90
00:04:52.946 --> 00:04:53.677
things like that.

91
00:04:53.677 --> 00:04:59.190
So groups really help simplify
administration and permissions.

92
00:04:59.190 --> 00:05:03.230
>> And that is absolutely the gold
star answer that we were looking for.

93
00:05:03.230 --> 00:05:05.899
The very fact is we can
individually assign every user

94
00:05:05.899 --> 00:05:07.570
that we want to be able to do this.

95
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:11.333
But now if it does change,
it also means exactly what Mike said,

96
00:05:11.333 --> 00:05:15.610
I'd have to go back in every place
that I assigned him and remove him.

97
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:18.870
Well instead, assigning it to a group,
then we can just remove

98
00:05:18.870 --> 00:05:22.530
users from the group,
it's not really such a big deal anymore.

99
00:05:22.530 --> 00:05:25.034
It makes it administratively easier And

100
00:05:25.034 --> 00:05:29.672
one of the key points in managing
eDiscovery is that the owners which we're

101
00:05:29.672 --> 00:05:34.395
gonna assign as far as permissions over
that site that we have to do this for.

102

Is gonna be those eDiscovery

00:05:37.197 --> 00:05:39.672
But we wanna actually

00:05:39.672 --> 00:05:43.560
they also have to be mail
enabled type of security groups.

105
00:05:43.560 --> 00:05:46.083
So it's not just that we can create

00:05:46.083 --> 00:05:49.791
It's not a Yammer group,
it's not a distribution group,

107
00:05:49.791 --> 00:05:54.355
it is a security group and
that is a key point that we want to make.

108
00:05:54.355 --> 00:05:58.861
If is not a mail enabled group,
now when I say that right, M-A-I-L.

109
00:05:58.861 --> 00:06:02.120
I know that sounds weird but
you know people go,

110
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:07.110
why does it have to be a mail, why,
so an email enabled group here.

111
00:06:07.110 --> 00:06:11.490
And Mike laughs at me, but the questions
that we have heard over time.

112
00:06:11.490 --> 00:06:12.280
>> Absolutely.

113
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:13.229
>> And you're just shaking your head.

114
00:06:13.229 --> 00:06:15.278
And they're like,
why are you shaking your head?

115
00:06:15.278 --> 00:06:18.220
It's no, email.

116
00:06:18.220 --> 00:06:20.130
I should have said email, you're right.

117
00:06:20.130 --> 00:06:22.540
I should have said email not mail enabled.

118
00:06:22.540 --> 00:06:25.410
But that's what we're
normally talking about here.

119
00:06:25.410 --> 00:06:27.110
So, the only way for

is gonna be an exchange,

We wanna get inside a recipients,

Mailboxes is usually the basic unit,

The great thing is in the web UI,

00:09:01.340 --> 00:09:04.370
So the way that we create a new

00:09:10.590 --> 00:09:17.030
You definitely need to know which group

If you choose this one, you're wrong.

00:09:19.360 --> 00:09:20.040
Okay?

171

If you choose this one,

The dynamic distribution group,

That's why I wanted to emphasis
this as you're going, no,

So if you need to create
one remember that this

It's not that they don't test you

They do test you on stuff like this where

00:09:48.540 --> 00:09:52.270

00:09:52.270 --> 00:09:56.600
Well, you've gotta know which one or

00:09:56.600 --> 00:10:01.526
So you are going to select
then the security group.

Notice here's the proper

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue setting up an eDiscovery site in SharePoint. They demonstrate adding the newly created security group to the site owners group using both the GUI and PowerShell.
episodes.title: Configure eDiscovery Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie begin their look at configuring additional email addresses in Exchange Online. Here they show you how to find the default email address, add an email alias, and change the default reply address.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their look at configuring additional email addresses in Exchange Online. Here the show you how to manage secondary email addresses and SIP addresses as well as begin to look at the steps to merge a new domain with a bulk add/remove of addresses.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie provide a detailed solution for bulk email address change. Ronnie demonstrates how to change a domain addresses on a per user basis through the GUI as well as a bulk migration using PowerShell. Tune in to learn how to automate this process.

00:29:10.690 --> 00:29:12.230
Well, that's not what it's asking,

516
00:29:12.230 --> 00:29:17.620
it's saying hey it wants you to replace
the domain name side for multiple users.

517
00:29:17.620 --> 00:29:20.550
And that is what we showed
right here in this show today.

518
00:29:20.550 --> 00:29:22.010
>> You know, Ronnie,
I can see the value and

519

understanding that from an exam

520

I mean this is a great demo especially for

Ronnie, you're really taken all

[LAUGH] So thank you for that.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie demonstrate how to create and manage external contacts, resources, and groups. First, Ronnie demonstrates how to generate a resource mailbox via the GUI and PowerShell. He also shows how to create a shared mailbox via the GUI as well as PowerShell.
episodes.title: Configure Contacts and Resources
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.399
Welcome to ITPro.TV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.399 --> 00:00:08.168
[MUSIC]

3

adding in of course different things

15

We're still going to be
doing some of that, but

now we're actually taking a look,

of course even groups as we start to look.

But one of the first ones that we

20

Hopefully, I'll be able to say that soon.

21
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:12.810
Usually, inside of an organization, right.

22
00:01:12.810 --> 00:01:17.460
We do have users that always

23

And they normally represent,

there is other things that

25

In terms of it, needs a calendar,

32

So for example in the building where

37

38

40

42

43

44
00:02:33.480 --> 00:02:38.336
So, instead what we can also do is

45
00:02:38.336 --> 00:02:40.700

46
00:02:40.700 --> 00:02:46.700
In which you now actually make a request
that conference room for a meeting.

47
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:49.800
That resource then can verify on
the calendar whether it's free or

48
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:52.480
whether it's busy, and notify

49

everything is actually open and available.

50
00:02:56.340 --> 00:03:00.910
So it might not actually be a person,
but we do need the ability to have that

51
00:03:00.910 --> 00:03:04.880
communication system going on to be
able to reserve that room if we need to.

52
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:07.700
To use it when it's actually necessary

53
00:03:07.700 --> 00:03:11.750
to allow people to understand when
they do have the availability for it.

54
00:03:11.750 --> 00:03:13.650
So that's what we're

55

All right, the great thing is you can

00:04:39.500 --> 00:04:41.020
So all that is possible.

For example, it might be where we do

And, we have to actually

that we also may have an equipment

So, yeah, once this ends up running here

But that's what we should

I can see that a mailbox was created.

It says failed to replicate the mailbox,

00:10:42.490 --> 00:10:45.740

00:00:33.570 --> 00:00:35.210

a little mini-series here.

00:00:37.710 --> 00:00:41.230

some point, Don, of doing this.

00:00:41.230 --> 00:00:46.360
But overall, though, as we're taking a
look at part three, Zach is exactly right.

16
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:50.930
We've been taking a lot of time taking
a look at configuring contacts, right,

17

and email addresses, and
that's a big part of it.

18

But the other part,
of course, are resources.

And at the very end of our last show,

Making sure that the contacts can get

And now we're moving on to one of

23
00:01:09.460 --> 00:01:12.530

24
00:01:12.530 --> 00:01:16.840
Inside of the world of Active Directory
networks that are out there, and

25
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:18.240
security boundaries.

00:01:18.240 --> 00:01:22.090
We think about two different grouping
types, one is a security grouping.

00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:25.110
But the other one is as important, even
though we don't think about it that way

00:01:25.110 --> 00:01:28.020

29
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:31.140
Now, when it comes down to distribution
groups, you might be wondering,

30
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:32.450

31
00:01:32.450 --> 00:01:36.120
It allows me to be able to send one email,
and

32
00:01:36.120 --> 00:01:39.320

in that distribution group.

33
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:43.021
So instead of me or Zack having to
type out 20 or 30 separate emails.

34
00:01:43.021 --> 00:01:46.132
Or even one email, and
then pasting everybody's name into.

35
00:01:46.132 --> 00:01:49.174
I add everybody into this
logical container that we called

36
00:01:49.174 --> 00:01:50.423

37
00:01:50.423 --> 00:01:52.837
And then I just send one
email to that group.

38
00:01:52.837 --> 00:01:54.448
And then it automatically says,

39
00:01:54.448 --> 00:01:57.940
okay, I'm gonna send it out to
everybody within that group.

40
00:01:57.940 --> 00:02:02.130
And now I've created an effective
distribution list, is what we've done.

41
00:02:02.130 --> 00:02:04.340
So we need to make sure
that we understand,

42
00:02:04.340 --> 00:02:08.310
of course then, how to create
this type of distribution group.

43
00:02:08.310 --> 00:02:11.480
And then some of the management

We, of course,

Because it really does give you a chance

settings and configurations.

In that distribution group,
that we need to understand.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach discuss how to configure personal archive policies and enable personal archives for mailboxes, as an alternative location to store historical data. In part 2 we see how to create retention tags additionally.

now all of a sudden they say, all right,

let's say that we

And what I want to do is I want to apply

to Lance himself.

You currently saw that when I showed you,
of course, these policies for Lance,

it wasn't actually there.

But for this one, we can do this, and

the way that we do this because

to assign this to Lance I

-CsConferencingPolicy on the identity

So lance@offficeprodemoco.onmicrosoft.com,

then I tell it what policy name.

it is here I have to do

Noft.

Press Enter there,

I get nothing that really does show

But I should now be able to go and

and let's see if everything is

392

So this gives me this ability then,

00:23:40.400 --> 00:23:44.470
I'm wondering what the check mark

even though I had it unchecked here on

So now I've turned off those

that will allow me to

397

So we can verify that everything

in the way that we wanna do this.

But setting it up just for

And we're gonna turn something like this

And I'm handling other

it probably needs to be turned on for

So even though we can use this with

So, thank you for stopping me cuz

1

>> I'm your host, Zach Memos for

00:00:20.840 --> 00:00:23.860
as we continue with configuring

7

8

Ronnie, thanks for joining us again.

>> Well, thank you again for

As we continue on,
we take a look at Skype services here, and

00:00:35.700 --> 00:00:39.000
what we have to kind of remember to do.

So now that we're actually
in the midst of this, let's

make sure that we review of just a little
bit of what we hit in part one as well.

14
00:00:46.510 --> 00:00:51.230
So, inside of part one, we talked about
some of the issues here with compliance.

15
00:00:51.230 --> 00:00:55.650
That as Office 365 is really
a collaboration service,

16
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:59.850
as well as email, and of course
other services that are out there.

17
00:00:59.850 --> 00:01:04.040
We also need to think about compliance,
and that has to do with searching for

18

information and communications that
go on inside of our business, and

19

if we're using Skype for Business, there

default because it's the native
way in which Skype for

21
00:01:16.020 --> 00:01:21.250
Business works, then we really have to

22
00:01:21.250 --> 00:01:24.620
And, so
we showed you that inside of the part one,

23

where we essentially turned off some

24
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:30.910
that allow us to get that all set up.

Then we of course talked about some of

26
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:41.330
And, now we are in the midst of also

27

Where we're not only showing how
we could configure a policy for

an individual user, but
we need to get into this idea of, well,

00:01:48.760 --> 00:01:51.430
just a little bit more

30
00:01:51.430 --> 00:01:55.140
>> Yeah, Ronnie, and so if we need

>> That's right.

33

So at this point,
even though we might say,

00:02:01.730 --> 00:02:04.950
I wanna set a compliance policy for
Zach himself.

And the problem we have is Zach's
probably not the only one we need to set

compliance for.

00:02:09.390 --> 00:02:14.120
So the great thing is there is a default

00:02:14.120 --> 00:02:19.170
it may not be set up exactly for
what you need it to be set up for, and

00:02:19.170 --> 00:02:25.030
this is where we have to go in and we must

Now, this is where it becomes a little

hey, we need this to be a global setting

00:02:33.530 --> 00:02:38.080
But we can't do it in the same way that

00:02:38.080 --> 00:02:42.020
we showed in the first part of our show,
okay?

44
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:46.010
What we need to do though is, we need to

00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:50.480
which is we're gonna be modifying what

46
00:02:50.480 --> 00:02:53.480
Now, the reason why this
is a little bit slow, and

47
00:02:53.480 --> 00:02:58.980
why I'm being a little bit laborious about
this, is because it has changed over time.

48
00:02:58.980 --> 00:03:03.670
There was a Microsoft Ignite

00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:06.650
look, we're changing

50

At part one I've kind of told

53

Can you create a brand new policy?

54
00:03:19.520 --> 00:03:20.280
Yes.

55
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:25.570
But you can't take existing policies that
are inside of Skype for Business and

56
00:03:25.570 --> 00:03:28.090
say all right, I'm gonna customize this
part, I'm gonna customize this part,

57
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:30.970
I'm I'm gonna do this, and
then make them all wrap up together.

58
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:32.960
They just don't want you to do that.

59
00:03:32.960 --> 00:03:36.450
So, when they do that, that means you
either have to pick from that, or

60
00:03:36.450 --> 00:03:39.220
you have to create a new one and apply it.

61
00:03:39.220 --> 00:03:44.860
The problem, though, is globally you can't
actually pick from any one of those,

62
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:48.230
and say, I'm just gonna take
that as a template, and

63
00:03:48.230 --> 00:03:53.190
override the global policy by putting
this one on top of the global one.

64
00:03:53.190 --> 00:03:54.900
They don't allow that to happen.

65
00:03:54.900 --> 00:03:58.070
That Ignite Conference essentially
changed everything, and

66
00:03:58.070 --> 00:04:02.700
that's why there's a little bit of you
know, some conundrum in this, because

67
00:04:02.700 --> 00:04:07.850
some of the commands that we were trying
to run before are no longer going to work.

68
00:04:07.850 --> 00:04:11.840
So now, now that we have
an understanding of what we need to do,

69
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:13.320
we need to be able to understand this.

70
00:04:13.320 --> 00:04:15.770
That what we're gonna do is,
we're take the policy

in which they did allow a little bit

00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:22.190
if you do this, this is gonna affect

73
00:04:22.190 --> 00:04:25.890
Make sure first that you know what
it's gonna affect before you do it.

74
00:04:25.890 --> 00:04:30.290
But now they allow you to globally change
that policy, and now you're off and

75
00:04:30.290 --> 00:04:31.290
you're ready to go.

76
00:04:31.290 --> 00:04:36.040
But just remember that part of Office 365
and Skype for Business, and getting these

77
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:40.610
policies set up the way they want to, we
normally don't affect anything like this,

78
00:04:40.610 --> 00:04:44.660
but now we are going to, and that is
something that they have recently changed.

79
00:04:44.660 --> 00:04:47.800
So, let's make sure that we
can show you how to do that.

80
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:53.150
The other thing about this, is this

81
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:57.540
So, when somebody says can you change

00:04:57.540 --> 00:05:01.850
But it's also only gonna be done

83
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:05.360
So that is something else that we'll
also need to make sure that we know

00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:06.850
as we do this.

85

All right, so here we are on PowerShell.

00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:14.250
I'm just gonna run my
get ps session command,

I'm still connected to Exchange,

I am connected to the Skype for

Now, remember, that I showed you earlier,

This really is, kind of, pieced and

So this is the last one that

And that is now opened and

96

So the first thing and
we're gonna set this up globally and

We wanna take a look at

00:05:51.890 --> 00:05:58.030
So if I do a get-cs conferencing

Policy and that is the policy

And that one I showed you where everything

Now if I press enter at this point,

So we can see that the true identity

Right now it's set to faults, okay?

So faults for

Now I had always tried to do this

But because they've changed this,

Right, I simply said I'm gonna

00:08:33.310 --> 00:08:35.820
And that should give me

00:08:35.820 --> 00:08:40.233
But now, since adding and
since they've updated anything,

So, for this one,

And instead of actually

what I actually need to do is

00:08:59.330 --> 00:09:01.367
Conferencing policy,

00:09:01.367 --> 00:09:06.872
give the name of the policy that

154
00:09:06.872 --> 00:09:13.741
Now I can go back in and start typing in

155
00:09:13.741 --> 00:09:17.890
And this disables

156
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:23.250
This one, I want it to actually
be set to true, because

00:09:23.250 --> 00:09:28.850
I want to truly disable that setting,

158
00:09:28.850 --> 00:09:35.240
The second one that we looked at was,
allow the OneNote or allow shared notes.

159
00:09:35.240 --> 00:09:37.390
That's the way that it's just here.

160
00:09:37.390 --> 00:09:40.580
And on this one,
I wanna set this one to faults.

161
00:09:40.580 --> 00:09:42.470
So I have to do the dollar sign, and

00:09:42.470 --> 00:09:46.430
I have to spell faults correctly,
how's that?

00:09:46.430 --> 00:09:53.200
Then I can do another dash and
this one will be EnableFileTransfer and

00:09:53.200 --> 00:09:56.360
I wanna make sure that one is false.

165
00:09:56.360 --> 00:10:02.812
And the last one is pretty much the same,
EnableP2PFileTansfer.

166
00:10:02.812 --> 00:10:07.971
And now that one should also be false,
here.

167
00:10:07.971 --> 00:10:09.652
So if that accepts it,

168
00:10:09.652 --> 00:10:15.230
I should be able to run the same command

00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:18.826
And we should now be able to see

170

So, the easiest way, right now,
that I can see that,

00:10:21.356 --> 00:10:23.339

172

And note that those are actually true,

173
00:10:26.620 --> 00:10:30.600
But then, I'll go back in, let me

174
00:10:31.770 --> 00:10:34.640
Maybe, it's not letting

Why is it not letting me click it?

That is the topic that we

Once everything is in the cloud though,

Is that,
we'll kind of provide the protection, and

00:02:31.578 --> 00:02:36.990

But if you don't have a ton, but

line utility to begin that download

So I'm really not showing it to you

So at this point,

00:30:06.480 --> 00:30:10.550

There we go, I need to go into

I've actually created two PST

One of them's not,

00:30:23.830 --> 00:30:26.883
But ones we have that,

this is where I can now

It's gonna be under Program Files, under

So once that's done,

And then import those PSTs into your

And so, there's others out

So do check out that 70-345 class for

And you'll see kind of the end

But overall though, that will allow

A really powerful tool when you have a

This is kinda the way to get around it

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach discuss 4.3 Plan for Exchange Online including Client requirements for archive, Exchange retention policies, managing Office 365 Compliance Protection Center (or Security & Compliance Center), alerts, permissions, classifications, and concluding part 1 with service assurance.
episodes.title: Plan for Exchange Online

Hey, Ronnie!

You are actually wearing a very

16

>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

It also means that it's time to jump into

Now this is a little bit unusual in terms

We've actually already

And instead of me trying

29

But we are gonna talk about

32

We all, of course,
one to actually think about as we say,

all right we're moving into

34
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:25.630
And so here's a few things that we
wanna make sure that we do cover and

35
00:01:25.630 --> 00:01:28.750
that we understand as we go into that.

36
00:01:28.750 --> 00:01:32.740
So one of the first topics that we
want to just talk about briefly here

37
00:01:32.740 --> 00:01:34.040
is gonna be planning for

38
00:01:34.040 --> 00:01:40.420
the idea of how do we want users to
be able to archive their information.

39
00:01:40.420 --> 00:01:41.500
And when it comes down to that,

40
00:01:41.500 --> 00:01:44.690
it's not that we don't want
users to archive information.

41
00:01:44.690 --> 00:01:45.960
Heck, that's almost a given,

42
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.880
that we want all of our users to be
able to archive the information.

43
00:01:49.880 --> 00:01:53.700
None of us wants to sort of go,
emails aren't important, and

44
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:57.050
then three weeks later, somebody says,
did you get an email like a month or

45
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:59.070
two ago and it was about this?

46
00:01:59.070 --> 00:02:04.090
And the user says, probably, but since
we're not archiving anymore, it's gone.

47
00:02:04.090 --> 00:02:05.110
>> So archiving is one thing,

48
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:08.270
what do we need to consider when
we're planning for archive?

49
00:02:08.270 --> 00:02:10.350
>> And that's what we have to get to,
right?

50
00:02:10.350 --> 00:02:14.310
So that idea of consideration
is not that we need to archive,

51
00:02:14.310 --> 00:02:15.810
is that what we need to plan for.

52
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:19.970
And when it comes down to that,
the planning part of it really needs for

53
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:22.890
us to think about
the ideas of retention and

54
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:27.940
how we get that retention to work as well
as the duration and the periods like that.

55
00:02:27.940 --> 00:02:29.980
Now, when we start to talk about that,

56
00:02:29.980 --> 00:02:33.050
it's actually fairly a little
bit more complex, right?

57
00:02:33.050 --> 00:02:35.690
The configuration side, when you do go in,

58
00:02:35.690 --> 00:02:39.950
you take a look at those
configuring Exchange Online shows.

59
00:02:39.950 --> 00:02:42.960
We show you exactly how
to create retention tags.

60
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:46.300
We show you how to go in there and
talk about retention policies and

61
00:02:46.300 --> 00:02:48.180
how to get all that stuff set up.

62
00:02:48.180 --> 00:02:50.750
So you do want that to happen.

63
00:02:50.750 --> 00:02:55.060
But one of the key things here is
the duration of that retention.

64
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:58.240
And also what is the action
we wanted to take for

65
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:02.130
that particular period of
retention once it's over.

66
00:03:02.130 --> 00:03:04.320
So everything that we create,
such as a policy or

67
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:07.410
a tag, it usually has those
elements involved in it.

68
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:14.700
A particular duration, as well as the idea
here of taking a look at the tags too.

69
00:03:14.700 --> 00:03:18.120
And the policy that there also has to
be an action associated with that.

70
00:03:18.120 --> 00:03:21.145
>> And that's something we're doing in
the web UI and also PowerShell, right?

71
00:03:21.145 --> 00:03:24.160
>> Yup, and we did show you
that inside of that episode.

72
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:26.380
Now let's just show you
a brief reminder here,

73
00:03:26.380 --> 00:03:29.910
at least in the web UI,
where you go to set that

74
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:33.920
because we are gonna get into that more

75
00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:36.540
This would had been great if it
will actually appear before that.

76
00:03:36.540 --> 00:03:38.230
But lets go and show you anyways.

77
00:03:38.230 --> 00:03:43.317
So here it is, I'm logged in as
the global administrator for my Exchange,

78
00:03:43.317 --> 00:03:47.500
Office 365 If I click on the Admin tile,

79
00:03:47.500 --> 00:03:52.200
that of course will bring me into
the Office 365 Admin center.

80
00:03:52.200 --> 00:03:54.130
At least in a moment it will.

81
00:03:54.130 --> 00:03:56.330
Looks like it's a little
bit sluggish today.

82
00:03:56.330 --> 00:04:00.640
If I scroll down on the navigation
over here on the left hand side I

83
00:04:00.640 --> 00:04:03.280
find the Admin icon.

84
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:04.843
Then I can click on Exchange.

85
00:04:08.021 --> 00:04:14.360
And once I'm actually inside of Exchange,
if it does come up here.

86
00:04:14.360 --> 00:04:15.440
And again, it's a little bit slow.

87
00:04:15.440 --> 00:04:19.570
We'll be able to see where we can create
the idea of these retention policies as

88
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:21.460
well as the tags coming in.

89
00:04:21.460 --> 00:04:26.570
So, it's a place that we really have to
get familiar with as we start to do this.

90
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:30.680
And we also need to talk about where
does that stuff come from too.

91
00:04:30.680 --> 00:04:33.490
So, when it comes down to the planning
of these different things,

92
00:04:33.490 --> 00:04:37.160
let me let it kind of fill in all it needs
to while we talk about some of the details

93
00:04:37.160 --> 00:04:42.460
on this idea of retention here,
is that we also need to talk about

94
00:04:42.460 --> 00:04:45.870
who comes up with this and
where does it actually happen.

95
00:04:45.870 --> 00:04:48.230
A lot of times,
you as the actual administrator,

96
00:04:48.230 --> 00:04:53.140
you don't get to make decisions on how
long you're going to retain e-mails.

97
00:04:53.140 --> 00:04:55.102
Somebody else is gonna make that decision.

98
00:04:55.102 --> 00:04:58.667
You're the one that's gonna have to
implement a policy that will enforce that

99
00:04:58.667 --> 00:05:00.180
decision for you.

100
00:05:00.180 --> 00:05:04.340
So in reality, in terms of businesses it
depends on the industry that you're in,

101
00:05:04.340 --> 00:05:07.630
it depends on your
organization's own policies.

102
00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:12.180
But what you want here in
terms of the archiving policy

103
00:05:12.180 --> 00:05:16.840
is to make sure that you have it match up
to whatever your security policies are.

104
00:05:16.840 --> 00:05:20.700
In terms of security, you wanna make
sure that you have that ability to say,

105
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:23.750
we have data up to this point in time, and

106
00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:27.270
what is gonna be retained and
what isn't gonna be retained.

107
00:05:27.270 --> 00:05:30.110
And that is gonna be very important
especially when it comes out to

108
00:05:30.110 --> 00:05:33.330
other matters that you have
to consider for Exchange.

109
00:05:33.330 --> 00:05:36.468
The very fact is,
today as such a litigious society, Zach,

110
00:05:36.468 --> 00:05:39.875
that people will say,
I don't care if it goes back ten years.

111
00:05:39.875 --> 00:05:42.055
I want that email.

112
00:05:42.055 --> 00:05:45.995
Now, somebody comes back into your company
and says, what do you mean I have it for

113
00:05:45.995 --> 00:05:47.365
the last eight years?

114
00:05:47.365 --> 00:05:49.655
So, you do have to plan for
things like this.

115
00:05:49.655 --> 00:05:53.355
It's not just an automatic,
we'll just hold it for six months.

116
00:05:53.355 --> 00:05:55.895
You've gotta be able to talk about that,
and that's actually kind of key too.

117
00:05:55.895 --> 00:05:57.985
>> Document, document,
document, absolutely.

118
00:05:57.985 --> 00:06:00.275
>> Yeah, it really is,
it's really about documentation, but

119
00:06:00.275 --> 00:06:03.655
it's also about making sure that
what our policies we set up here for

120
00:06:03.655 --> 00:06:08.460
the archiving lines up to what ever
your company's security policy is.

121
00:06:08.460 --> 00:06:10.260
If you have those things different,

122
00:06:10.260 --> 00:06:14.740
you're gonna end up finding yourself
in an unusual situation especially if

123
00:06:14.740 --> 00:06:19.750
something illegal arises that is not
gonna be what you expect it to be.

124
00:06:19.750 --> 00:06:23.035
Your security policy will say you're
supposed to retain it up to five years.

125
00:06:23.035 --> 00:06:25.225
You're gonna say I only have data for
up to three years,

126
00:06:25.225 --> 00:06:29.600
cuz that's the way I set the policy, and
now that's when you start having issues.

127
00:06:29.600 --> 00:06:34.350
So the best practice, right,
get together with your security team and

128
00:06:34.350 --> 00:06:35.795

I'm your host Zack Memos, for

>> Well thank you again for

as we start to take a look at some of the

So when we start Planning for

we really did talk about using

We also set up of
course,archiving a little bit.

And made sure that you realized,

So we really talked about it and

But go back in to configuring

We spent a pretty good bid of time in

20

So, we don't want you to feel like I
know that hey did he just do this?

21

This is a repeat episode and
it's not a repeat episode.

22

But it was really a planning stage,

23
00:01:10.350 --> 00:01:14.041
and of course we talked about the ideas
of planning and what we need there.

24
00:01:14.041 --> 00:01:20.420
Now, here's where the Security &
Compliance Center doesn't really fit in.

25
00:01:20.420 --> 00:01:25.620
When it comes down to Exchange,
Exchange has been around for a long time.

26
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:30.320
Actually even before Office 365
was around, Exchange was around.

27
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:34.170
So that product is a very matured product.

28
00:01:34.170 --> 00:01:37.530
It has set essentially
the standard in how you

29
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:40.830
deal with like the big Microsoft products.

30
00:01:40.830 --> 00:01:43.790
When it comes down to it,
it is kind of the big guy in the room.

31
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:48.909
It knows exactly what it wants to do, and
it doesn't like change a ton of times.

32
00:01:48.909 --> 00:01:51.748
And the reason why I wanted
to mention that is that,

33
00:01:51.748 --> 00:01:54.720
when it comes down to
Security & Compliance Center,

34
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:58.303
it may actually affect just
about everything in Office 365.

35
00:01:58.303 --> 00:02:02.194
But when they started saying,
let's also do this with Exchange,

36
00:02:02.194 --> 00:02:05.010
the Exchange product itself said, no way.

37
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:07.520
I'm the big brother here.

38
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:08.550
I'm not changing.

39
00:02:08.550 --> 00:02:11.930
I will do things the way that I do things,
and

40

you're just gonna have to
learn how to deal with that.

41
00:02:13.880 --> 00:02:19.040
So you will see certain things in
that Security & Compliance Center.

42
00:02:19.040 --> 00:02:21.500
Which you're not gonna be
able to effect a change.

43
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:22.940
That's what it comes down to.

44
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:25.980
So that means we need to spend more
time in the Exchange admin center,

45
00:02:25.980 --> 00:02:27.140
to be able to do this.

46
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:30.850
So one of those features that
we definitely did configure and

47
00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:35.575
that we wanna talk about,
is of course enabling the legal hold.

48
00:02:35.575 --> 00:02:38.760
It's what we want to do especially
when it comes down to Exchange.

49
00:02:38.760 --> 00:02:40.160
Now when we start talking about,

50
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:43.430
let's make sure that we understand
what we mean by a legal hold here.

51
00:02:43.430 --> 00:02:47.000
This helps us to preserve all of
the mailbox content for somebody that has

52
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:52.360
an Exchange mailbox, including deleted
items and modified items, as well.

53
00:02:52.360 --> 00:02:56.570
User archives,
deleted items are normally going to be,

54
00:02:56.570 --> 00:02:58.740
when it comes down to a legal hold.

55
00:02:58.740 --> 00:03:02.460
They're going to be held there for
a particular hold time,

56
00:03:02.460 --> 00:03:08.360
however long we actually set that policy
for, or until we say it can be removed.

57
00:03:08.360 --> 00:03:12.870
So it can be either permanent that's
there until we go, we're done with it.

58
00:03:12.870 --> 00:03:15.630
Or we can set it for
a particular period of time and

59
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:19.360
then we're no longer holding it,
we're no longer having to do that.

60
00:03:19.360 --> 00:03:22.110
So, that's the way the legal
hold essentially works.

61
00:03:22.110 --> 00:03:24.620
The great thing is it works very well.

62
00:03:24.620 --> 00:03:27.580
The standard default size for
this legal hold for

63
00:03:27.580 --> 00:03:30.960
somebody's mailbox,
is normally 30 gigabytes.

64
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:33.670
Now, that's a pretty darn big size.

65
00:03:33.670 --> 00:03:36.430
Most of us are never going
to use that much, but

66
00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:38.420
that's the default size that it sets up.

67
00:03:38.420 --> 00:03:42.550
If you need more it's strange, it will
allow you to save more especially when

68
00:03:42.550 --> 00:03:45.830
you're archiving and then you're
also putting a legal hold on it.

69
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:48.760
But you might find out that it may also
cost you a little bit more too, but

70
00:03:48.760 --> 00:03:50.830
just kinda realize it is there.

71
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:53.710
>> Ronnie, this legal hold,
is that an example of yes?

72
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:57.430
>> Yes, when it comes down to it,
it's one of those examples in which we go,

73
00:03:57.430 --> 00:04:00.490
can I do this in the Security
& Compliance Center?

74
00:04:00.490 --> 00:04:03.590
No, but do I need to go into
the Exchange atmosphere and do it?

75
00:04:03.590 --> 00:04:07.910
Yes, so this is one of those in which
we're not gonna be able to manage that.

76
00:04:07.910 --> 00:04:11.748
So when it comes down to it,
when I said that Security & Compliance

77
00:04:11.748 --> 00:04:16.217
center do I have to do everything here,
or is there one place for me to do this?

78
00:04:16.217 --> 00:04:20.113
Well in that point, yes, this is something
you have to do only in Exchange, so

79
00:04:20.113 --> 00:04:22.192
that's what we're talking about here.

80
00:04:22.192 --> 00:04:26.266
Now, once you set this up especially
if you set up a time period,

81
00:04:26.266 --> 00:04:30.417
some of the elements that you do
have to know, that default time or

82
00:04:30.417 --> 00:04:33.030
that default size is kinda key.

83
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:36.970
And then, what does it mean when you
set up a timeline for it to hold?

84
00:04:36.970 --> 00:04:41.420
Well, this is normally set from
the day that it is actually received

85
00:04:41.420 --> 00:04:45.930
into your mailbox, or
the day that you create the item itself.

86
00:04:45.930 --> 00:04:48.130
So it's not one year since
the day that you have,

87
00:04:49.820 --> 00:04:52.940
I enabled legal hold on Zack's mailbox.

88
00:04:52.940 --> 00:04:54.518
When Zack actually-
>> You did?

89
00:04:54.518 --> 00:04:55.092
>> Three days.

90
00:04:55.092 --> 00:04:58.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, three days from now if he creates

91
00:04:58.290 --> 00:05:03.620
an email, it's from the time he created it
until whatever that retention period is.

92
00:05:03.620 --> 00:05:06.330
So if I set it for a year,
it's a year from that time.

93
00:05:06.330 --> 00:05:09.170
It's not a year from today
if I set it up today.

94
00:05:09.170 --> 00:05:13.360
So, just make sure you understand a year
from the day that you create it, or

95
00:05:13.360 --> 00:05:16.420
the day that I sent Zack the email.

96
00:05:16.420 --> 00:05:18.680
And it's a years time from that.

97
00:05:18.680 --> 00:05:24.120
So it's kind of this unusual rolling
calendar of things that's happening that

98
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:29.820
even though when someone says well, how do
you know when it begins and when it ends.

99
00:05:29.820 --> 00:05:30.786
You really don't.

100
00:05:30.786 --> 00:05:33.628
If you reset it for five years from now,

101
00:05:33.628 --> 00:05:37.765
that means five years until
the very last email you send,

102
00:05:37.765 --> 00:05:42.699
it's five years even from that date
that that last item can be held.

103
00:05:42.699 --> 00:05:45.452
But all those other ones that
might have been sent years and

104
00:05:45.452 --> 00:05:47.362
previous, that were two years before or

105
00:05:47.362 --> 00:05:51.510
