00:31:19.910 --> 00:31:22.250
For ITProTV, thanks for
watching, I'm Zach.

560
00:31:22.250 --> 00:31:23.150
>> And I'm Ronnie.

561
00:31:23.150 --> 00:31:24.755
>> See you next time.

562
00:31:24.755 --> 00:31:30.633
[MUSIC]

563
00:31:30.633 --> 00:31:32.710
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach discuss enabling external access, and managing domain settings in Skype for Business.
episodes.title: Manage Skype Global Settings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.085
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.085 --> 00:00:06.279
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.279 --> 00:00:07.807
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.807 --> 00:00:11.902
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.902 --> 00:00:16.990
>> Thank you for choosing ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.990 --> 00:00:21.647
I'm your host Zack Memos for
enabling Office 365 Services, and

7
00:00:21.647 --> 00:00:26.228
today we're gonna be looking at
Managing Skype Global Settings.

8
00:00:26.228 --> 00:00:28.965
This is gonna be Part One with our IT pro,
Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:28.965 --> 00:00:29.799
How are you, Ronnie?

10
00:00:29.799 --> 00:00:30.629
>> How are you doing?

11
00:00:30.629 --> 00:00:32.961
>> I'm doing great and
I can't wait til we get into this topic,

12
00:00:32.961 --> 00:00:34.790
because I think it's exciting.

13
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:37.863
>> It's really one this topics that,
as an IT administrator,

14
00:00:37.863 --> 00:00:40.890
once we're actually going to
take a look at Office 365.

15
00:00:40.890 --> 00:00:44.150
You're gonna really need to be
familiar with some of these global

16
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:45.360
settings here, right?

17
00:00:45.360 --> 00:00:48.940
The settings that really aren't
per user or end user based.

18
00:00:48.940 --> 00:00:53.270
These are settings that we want to make
sure that we understand, that must be

19
00:00:53.270 --> 00:00:59.260
there for our Skype for Business to work
well across the entire organization.

20
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:03.618
So it's important as we start to set this
up that we understand first what those

21
00:01:03.618 --> 00:01:04.485
settings are.

22
00:01:04.485 --> 00:01:09.157
And then, of course, what we have to do to
go about making sure that they're on or

23
00:01:09.157 --> 00:01:11.840
off or anything else that we have to do.

24
00:01:11.840 --> 00:01:15.460
So we're gonna be taking a look at
multiple topics during the show.

25
00:01:15.460 --> 00:01:18.650
We're probably gonna spend a little bit
more time here at the beginning, and

26
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:21.920
then you'll probably see, we'll probably
break this up into at least a Part Two.

27
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:24.220
And may even go into a Part Three,
for all I know.

28
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:25.030
But overall though,

29
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:28.630
that is what we're actually going
to begin by taking a look at.

30
00:01:28.630 --> 00:01:32.870
So, when we start talking about
the idea of setting up for what we call

31
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:38.430
external access, or enabling external
access, this is kind of a key point.

32
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:41.074
When you get your Office
365 subscriptions,

33
00:01:41.074 --> 00:01:45.524
everybody that has access to the Office
365 subscription that has the Skype for

34
00:01:45.524 --> 00:01:47.345
Business a part of that, right?

35
00:01:47.345 --> 00:01:49.637
Make sure you go in and
you check your subscription plan,

36
00:01:49.637 --> 00:01:51.250
see if that's happening.

37
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:53.960
They can communicate all day long, okay?

38
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:57.026
They will have the client
on their computers, and

39
00:01:57.026 --> 00:02:00.314
they can use that to actually build and
communicate.

40
00:02:00.314 --> 00:02:05.180
Works great and you'll be very happy
with the result that you'll get.

41
00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:07.750
But there are going to be times,

42
00:02:07.750 --> 00:02:12.550
of course, that you'll need to
communicate outside of your organization.

43
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:16.620
And you've got options that you
have available there to do this.

44
00:02:16.620 --> 00:02:21.560
So for example, Zack, what can end up
happening is that you go, all right,

45
00:02:21.560 --> 00:02:23.610
I'm gonna use Skype for
Business, but really just for

46
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:27.090
the instant messaging and
internal communications.

47
00:02:27.090 --> 00:02:30.380
Then you can go out and say, hey,
I wanna talk to another company about

48
00:02:30.380 --> 00:02:33.760
implementing a phone system for
us in the business.

49
00:02:33.760 --> 00:02:35.393
And they can, of course, help you and

50
00:02:35.393 --> 00:02:37.959
you can set up different phone
systems to make that happen.

51
00:02:37.959 --> 00:02:41.539
You can even go to your telephone company
and say, here is what we actually need,

52
00:02:41.539 --> 00:02:43.860
and they can help you set
that up if you want to.

53
00:02:43.860 --> 00:02:45.360
So that is an option for you.

54
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:47.160
But when something like that happens,

55
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:50.120
it also means that they might have
to bring in some extra equipment.

56
00:02:50.120 --> 00:02:53.450
Because you're probably hosting
your own external or internal

57
00:02:53.450 --> 00:02:56.950
type of phone switch ,and making sure
that all those features are up there and

58
00:02:56.950 --> 00:02:59.630
available, but you really don't have to.

59
00:02:59.630 --> 00:03:01.933
If you actually start to enable Skype for

60
00:03:01.933 --> 00:03:05.318
Business to do that for you,
by enabling external access,

61
00:03:05.318 --> 00:03:09.534
it really takes kind of some of the
headache away from you having to worry.

62
00:03:09.534 --> 00:03:11.050
Is it something here?

63
00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:12.832
Well, it's always gonna be in the cloud.

64
00:03:12.832 --> 00:03:14.840
And in Skype for business,
a lot of it is, for

65
00:03:14.840 --> 00:03:17.160
us, just knowing what the services are.

66
00:03:17.160 --> 00:03:19.010
They've already figured
out how it actually works.

67
00:03:19.010 --> 00:03:24.051
You don't have to have another technician
that comes out every once in a while,

68
00:03:24.051 --> 00:03:25.715
you have a one place shop.

69
00:03:25.715 --> 00:03:28.807
But with Skype for Business the solution,
at least at that part,

70
00:03:28.807 --> 00:03:31.574
is really just us saying,
all right, how do we enable it?

71
00:03:31.574 --> 00:03:32.784
How do we get it done?

72
00:03:32.784 --> 00:03:34.690
How do we actually make that happen?

73
00:03:34.690 --> 00:03:39.530
So that's what we really
want to think about, okay?

74
00:03:39.530 --> 00:03:42.650
Now, when it comes down to external users,
who are we talking about?

75
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:45.610
Well, anybody outside of your
organization first, right?

76
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:49.250
So as long as people are outside of your
organization and you want to be able to

77
00:03:49.250 --> 00:03:54.210
communicate with them outside, or you want
them to communicate with you as well.

78
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:56.590
You're gonna need to enable for
external access.

79
00:03:56.590 --> 00:04:01.435
It could also be that,
inside of your Office 365 organization,

80
00:04:01.435 --> 00:04:05.780
that you are hosting for
multiple domains as well.

81
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:06.860
When you're doing that,

82
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:11.340
you also need to enable that for
the external access as well.

83
00:04:11.340 --> 00:04:16.221
Even between domains that are internal,
you'll need to enable the external access.

84
00:04:16.221 --> 00:04:20.797
And, of course, if you want your
users internally to use Skype for

85
00:04:20.797 --> 00:04:24.160
Business to contact
outside the organization.

86
00:04:24.160 --> 00:04:29.010
In other words you go, I don't really want
another system, I don't want to have to

87
00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:33.270
pay another gigantic amount of money to
implement a true PBX in my network here.

88
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:38.704
Then, yes, using Skype for Business,
enabling the external access,

89
00:04:38.704 --> 00:04:42.361
will now allow you to use Skype to
really allow you to reach out and

90
00:04:42.361 --> 00:04:44.961
connect even outside of your organization.

91
00:04:44.961 --> 00:04:49.738
So all of that is part of the process in
what we're actually going to be talking

92
00:04:49.738 --> 00:04:50.670
about.

93
00:04:50.670 --> 00:04:54.297
And, of course, showing you how to
verify or make sure that it's on and

94
00:04:54.297 --> 00:04:55.091
enabled here.

95
00:04:55.091 --> 00:04:58.924
So that is what we're actually
gonna take a look at now, and

96
00:04:58.924 --> 00:05:03.373
like everything else there are some
complexities to this that don't

97
00:05:03.373 --> 00:05:07.930
always have to do just directly
with Skype for Business, too.

98
00:05:07.930 --> 00:05:11.150
So let's start off there, and then we'll
talk about some of the other things that

99
00:05:11.150 --> 00:05:14.730
we may have to think about and
choose as well.

100
00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:22.442
So here on my computer I'm going to
get logged into the Office 365 domain.

101
00:05:22.442 --> 00:05:24.858
Let me see if I can type this password in.

102
00:05:28.243 --> 00:05:29.160
>> The super secret password.

103
00:05:29.160 --> 00:05:32.930
>> The super secret password that
I can remember sometimes, but

104
00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:33.970
not all the time here.

105
00:05:35.440 --> 00:05:36.690
And once I'm inside,

106
00:05:36.690 --> 00:05:41.050
I need to get into the Skype for Business
Admin Portal is where I need to go.

107
00:05:41.050 --> 00:05:46.042
So I'm going to click on the Admin tile,
and that will lead me, of course,

108
00:05:46.042 --> 00:05:48.995
to the Office 365 Admin Center, maybe.

109
00:05:48.995 --> 00:05:49.703
Try it again, there we go.

110
00:05:51.523 --> 00:05:55.469
Once we're actually in the Admin Center,
over on the lower left-hand corner

111
00:05:55.469 --> 00:05:58.714
I should also find the Admin icon
in that navigation bar as well.

112
00:05:58.714 --> 00:06:04.400
Things going a little bit slow this
afternoon for Office 365 here.

113
00:06:04.400 --> 00:06:07.040
Just kind of slowly but
surely creeping in.

114
00:06:08.110 --> 00:06:09.780
So I'm gonna scroll down to the bottom.

115
00:06:11.100 --> 00:06:17.300
Look for, of course, the Admin icon,
select Skype for Business.

116
00:06:17.300 --> 00:06:21.037
So from the Web UI standpoint
it's not really difficult,

117
00:06:21.037 --> 00:06:24.420
but it is something that, if you think
that you're just preparing for the exam.

118
00:06:24.420 --> 00:06:27.170
That you go,
I'll figure it out on the exam,

119
00:06:27.170 --> 00:06:30.650
it's not gonna help you,
it is buried a bit in here.

120
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:32.840
So even if you get to this
point where you have Skype for

121
00:06:32.840 --> 00:06:36.380
Business, notice on the left-hand
side as it's populating in.

122
00:06:36.380 --> 00:06:40.910
There's still a lot of options going
on over here on the left-hand side

123
00:06:40.910 --> 00:06:43.900
that you have to actually
be able to get set up.

124
00:06:43.900 --> 00:06:48.875
Now, once we're actually here,
we now can go into organization,

125
00:06:48.875 --> 00:06:50.070
is where we want to go.

126
00:06:51.230 --> 00:06:54.090
And then, inside of organization,

127
00:06:54.090 --> 00:06:58.525
it's gonna be here under
the external communications.

128
00:06:58.525 --> 00:07:02.647
And in the external communications,
just like it sounds to set up for

129
00:07:02.647 --> 00:07:07.342
external users connecting in, there's
gonna be a couple of different things

130
00:07:07.342 --> 00:07:11.200
that we really want to pay attention
here as we start to see this.

131
00:07:11.200 --> 00:07:14.763
So let me zoom in just a little bit so
that you can see it better.

132
00:07:14.763 --> 00:07:18.334
You can control access to Skype for
Business users and

133
00:07:18.334 --> 00:07:21.570
other organizations in one of two ways.

134
00:07:21.570 --> 00:07:26.250
You can block specific domains, but
allow access to everything else.

135
00:07:26.250 --> 00:07:30.760
Or allow specific domains, but
block access to everyone else.

136
00:07:30.760 --> 00:07:34.540
And we had talked about this concept in
earlier episodes, Zack, you and I did.

137
00:07:34.540 --> 00:07:36.410
We talked about black listing and
white listing.

138
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:41.280
It's essentially saying you need to
pick which one you're going to chose.

139
00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:44.590
So that is up to you on how
you chose to set that up.

140
00:07:44.590 --> 00:07:46.320
Now, you might be saying,
well Ronnie, which one's best?

141
00:07:46.320 --> 00:07:49.952
It's really up to your organization's
security policy at that point,

142
00:07:49.952 --> 00:07:51.388
of how you chose to do stuff.

143
00:07:51.388 --> 00:07:54.672
So I wish I could tell you, this is
the way that you should set it up, and

144
00:07:54.672 --> 00:07:56.582
this is the only way you should set it up.

145
00:07:56.582 --> 00:08:00.296
But I might actually be violating
your company's security policy.

146
00:08:00.296 --> 00:08:05.820
So make sure you find out from those
guys which one that you should.

147
00:08:05.820 --> 00:08:08.330
For me, if I were doing it and
I was the one to set it up,

148
00:08:08.330 --> 00:08:10.440
I would say whitelisting is the way to go.

149
00:08:10.440 --> 00:08:15.590
In other words, allow who I want to
allow in but block everybody else.

150
00:08:15.590 --> 00:08:17.100
But you might not be able to do that.

151
00:08:17.100 --> 00:08:19.100
And what I mean by that is let's say,
for an example,

152
00:08:19.100 --> 00:08:21.950
that you have a sales team, okay?

153
00:08:21.950 --> 00:08:25.730
The idea of blocking everybody but
who you want to allow access to,

154
00:08:26.740 --> 00:08:31.740
now you're kind of limiting
your scope of business, right?

155
00:08:31.740 --> 00:08:33.470
Where you go, yeah,
I'm only gonna allow these users.

156
00:08:33.470 --> 00:08:37.370
Well, that'd be silly if I want people
to buy, I don't really care who buys,

157
00:08:37.370 --> 00:08:39.300
I just people to buy from me.

158
00:08:39.300 --> 00:08:43.670
So, you do have to pay attention to
what you're really trying to do.

159
00:08:43.670 --> 00:08:48.260
So, it's not a, I wish I could say
here it is, simple turn key solution.

160
00:08:48.260 --> 00:08:50.450
Do it my way, and it'll work every time.

161
00:08:50.450 --> 00:08:54.600
I can't do that, I wish I could say
that I knew all the answers on that one.

162
00:08:54.600 --> 00:08:56.940
But on this one here,
that's what you'll choose.

163
00:08:57.950 --> 00:09:03.290
Now, notice that you have, once you choose
that, what are you going to do here?

164
00:09:03.290 --> 00:09:06.770
Except for blocked domains, okay?

165
00:09:06.770 --> 00:09:12.400
Or on only for allowed domains here.

166
00:09:12.400 --> 00:09:15.410
So external access only for
allowed domains,

167
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:20.480
that is by far the most restrictive
that we have available to, okay?

168
00:09:20.480 --> 00:09:24.600
Then, except for blocked domains,
means allow everybody else except for

169
00:09:24.600 --> 00:09:25.890
the ones I blocked.

170
00:09:25.890 --> 00:09:29.410
That to me sounds more natural for
a company that may have a sales team.

171
00:09:29.410 --> 00:09:34.410
That goes, no don't block somebody that's
calling me to buy something from me,

172
00:09:34.410 --> 00:09:35.351
that would be insane [LAUGH].

173
00:09:35.351 --> 00:09:37.850
>> Not a good thing.
>> That's definitely not a good thing

174
00:09:37.850 --> 00:09:39.160
when we start doing that.

175
00:09:39.160 --> 00:09:43.686
So here, we definitely want to pay
attention and then probably the one you

176
00:09:43.686 --> 00:09:47.410
don't want to do,
which is to just let it be completely off.

177
00:09:47.410 --> 00:09:49.034
Now, is a possible?

178
00:09:49.034 --> 00:09:53.762
Yes, you may chose this particular option
and go, I'm not gonna worry about blocking

179
00:09:53.762 --> 00:09:57.262
anything, I'm not gonna worry
about whitelisting anything,

180
00:09:57.262 --> 00:10:00.602
I'm just gonna allow it to do
what I want it to do here, okay?

181
00:10:00.602 --> 00:10:04.469
So that does give us this ability to do so
if we choose that.

182
00:10:04.469 --> 00:10:08.990
Now, once we select which one
we're going to do, right?

183
00:10:08.990 --> 00:10:13.380
So if I choose the more restrictive
of the two just as an example here,

184
00:10:13.380 --> 00:10:16.990
then I'm going to skip over this one for
a moment here.

185
00:10:16.990 --> 00:10:19.920
Because it is a little bit weird and
I'll come back to that,

186
00:10:19.920 --> 00:10:21.970
because if not I'll go
on a sidetrack Zach.

187
00:10:21.970 --> 00:10:24.340
Don't let me do that too much or

188
00:10:24.340 --> 00:10:27.620
we'll really be heading out
to the weeds at times here.

189
00:10:27.620 --> 00:10:32.080
But, this first one up here just says,
all right, here's what we wanna do.

190
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:35.478
And then the way that you can figure
that option is you come down here, okay?

191
00:10:36.860 --> 00:10:40.700
We're not really addressing the thing
right in the middle, which is strange.

192
00:10:40.700 --> 00:10:42.610
I don't know why they chose
to do this because this is

193
00:10:42.610 --> 00:10:43.940
actually a separate option.

194
00:10:44.960 --> 00:10:45.900
And it really is.

195
00:10:45.900 --> 00:10:48.800
So, to me, it's a little bit
strange why they would do that.

196
00:10:48.800 --> 00:10:51.490
Logically, for me, I would have
put these two together, right?

197
00:10:51.490 --> 00:10:54.640
External access blocked or
allowed domains.

198
00:10:54.640 --> 00:10:55.717
>> It makes sense.

199
00:10:55.717 --> 00:10:58.607
>> Then you click + here,
and it's here that

200
00:10:58.607 --> 00:11:03.201
you enter the domain name that you
want to add in to allow for, okay?

201
00:11:03.201 --> 00:11:05.910
If you select that on,
it's the one that you're gonna block.

202
00:11:05.910 --> 00:11:09.860
So, it makes sense, logically,
we understand that.

203
00:11:09.860 --> 00:11:12.540
So, those are some of the options
that you do have available.

204
00:11:13.740 --> 00:11:16.580
This one right here in the middle, okay?

205
00:11:16.580 --> 00:11:21.330
This is a little bit more unusual for
us where what we're trying to do here is

206
00:11:21.330 --> 00:11:26.990
we're trying to manage for just regular
Skype consumer connectivity, okay?

207
00:11:26.990 --> 00:11:28.347
Now, what we mean by that,

208
00:11:28.347 --> 00:11:32.010
notice it says public instant
messaging connectivity here.

209
00:11:32.010 --> 00:11:33.210
Let people use Skype for

210
00:11:33.210 --> 00:11:38.370
Business to communicate with Skype
users outside of your organization.

211
00:11:38.370 --> 00:11:41.770
Now, notice the way that it
actually words it right here, Zach.

212
00:11:41.770 --> 00:11:45.340
And this is where we actually do
see a couple of things, right?

213
00:11:45.340 --> 00:11:52.430
Notice the way it words it over here,
Skype for Business and then Skype users.

214
00:11:52.430 --> 00:11:55.920
Notice this part doesn't say Skype for
Business users, or

215
00:11:55.920 --> 00:11:59.800
other Skype for
Business organizations or people.

216
00:11:59.800 --> 00:12:02.130
And what they're really
talking about is that, hey,

217
00:12:02.130 --> 00:12:06.210
there are people that are not part of
a Skype for Business organization.

218
00:12:06.210 --> 00:12:10.500
And they still want to
communicate with you using Skype.

219
00:12:10.500 --> 00:12:15.220
Well, if you have this one unchecked,
and mine was checked by default.

00:26:01.340 --> 00:26:05.540
And the great thing is I've only got just
a few minutes left for this episode.

445
00:26:05.540 --> 00:26:08.120
Remember this one here, okay?

446
00:26:08.120 --> 00:26:09.630
So remember this, Zach?

447
00:26:09.630 --> 00:26:13.890
I was talking about this,
public IM connectivity, and

448
00:26:13.890 --> 00:26:16.110
we talked about what this is about here.

449
00:26:16.110 --> 00:26:20.260
Well, of course that means that
we can also do this inside of

00:26:20.260 --> 00:26:24.330
PowerShell as well to get this one set up.

451
00:26:24.330 --> 00:26:26.268
It's kind of running just
about the same command here.

452
00:26:26.268 --> 00:26:32.281
Set-CsTenant.

453
00:26:32.281 --> 00:26:35.337
I don't know why that's so
hard for me to spell, but it is.

454
00:26:35.337 --> 00:26:39.705
Tenant Configuration and

455
00:26:39.705 --> 00:26:44.077
then AllowPublicUsers.

456
00:26:47.573 --> 00:26:50.980
And then I can set this to true or false.

457
00:26:50.980 --> 00:26:52.130
So I'm gonna set it to True.

458
00:26:52.130 --> 00:26:54.149
Now it was already checked by default.

459
00:26:55.230 --> 00:27:01.840
Now let me make sure that we kind
of zoom in here, for just a moment.

460
00:27:01.840 --> 00:27:05.820
Now, this is not exactly something
that you'll see on the exam.

461
00:27:05.820 --> 00:27:10.640
But make sure you take a look, especially
at these commands that are listed here,

462
00:27:10.640 --> 00:27:12.890
as you start to set
something like this up.

463
00:27:13.950 --> 00:27:16.730
Doing what I just did
here is the equivalent

464
00:27:17.930 --> 00:27:23.520
of what we would actually see here
inside of the web UI as well.

465
00:27:23.520 --> 00:27:27.144
So this whole page that they made so
beautifully for us and

466
00:27:27.144 --> 00:27:30.098
they gave us such a nice
intuitive way to do it.

467
00:27:30.098 --> 00:27:33.983
Then they said, here's what you also
need to know for the exam, too.

468
00:27:33.983 --> 00:27:37.820
You've got to actually
know what to put there.

469
00:27:37.820 --> 00:27:41.710
Well, creating a domain is probably
one of the harder ones to remember,

470
00:27:41.710 --> 00:27:42.235
but it's simple.

471
00:27:42.235 --> 00:27:45.537
New-EdgeDomainPattern, figure out what
your domain pattern is, add it in.

472
00:27:45.537 --> 00:27:49.378
And then, once you do that,
you're gonna create that list.

473
00:27:49.378 --> 00:27:53.333
The way to apply it is right here, okay?

474
00:27:53.333 --> 00:27:58.122
The last one is allowing that consumer
Skype user to be able to connect

475
00:27:58.122 --> 00:27:59.865
into our organization.

476
00:27:59.865 --> 00:28:05.580
It all fits right here the way
that we actually want it to.

477
00:28:05.580 --> 00:28:09.359
It really does help us out when we
actually do need these settings to

478
00:28:09.359 --> 00:28:09.904
come up.

479
00:28:09.904 --> 00:28:14.486
And now you actually not only see where
it logically fits in in the web UI.

480
00:28:14.486 --> 00:28:19.331
You also now see where it also fits in for
the PowerShell as well, and

481
00:28:19.331 --> 00:28:24.300
that is what we're doing is setting up for
external access.

482
00:28:24.300 --> 00:28:27.970
There's a lot more for us to go, but
Zach, I have talked a long time and

483
00:28:27.970 --> 00:28:30.890
that probably means I've almost
run out of time here too.

484
00:28:30.890 --> 00:28:32.430
>> But we've enjoyed that as well.

485
00:28:32.430 --> 00:28:36.200
Manage Skype global settings
Part 2 will be coming up.

486
00:28:36.200 --> 00:28:38.380
Make sure to review Part 1.

487
00:28:38.380 --> 00:28:39.820
And Ronnie, thanks very much.

488
00:28:39.820 --> 00:28:47.030
And thank you for watching ITProTV as we
continue to enable Office 365 services.

489
00:28:47.030 --> 00:28:48.210
I'm your host Zach Memes.

490
00:28:48.210 --> 00:28:49.070
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

491
00:28:49.070 --> 00:28:50.228
>> And we will see you next time.

492
00:28:50.228 --> 00:28:58.784
[MUSIC]

493
00:28:58.784 --> 00:29:01.109
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach are now able to show the changes made in part 1 Manage Skype Global Settings that can take up to 24 hours to process, including the assigning of phone numbers, working in Web UI & PowerShell.

WEBVTT

This is the addendum or

So

>> When you start to take a look at this,

So let's get back to where we were

00:01:18.220 --> 00:01:21.040
We were talking about making sure
that we can get the Skype for

00:01:21.040 --> 00:01:24.770
Business, and the Cloud PBX all set up.

We're just taking a look at voice,

00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:34.200
And what you have everything set up,
you'll end up seeing, now instead of

34

35
00:01:37.450 --> 00:01:38.584
Currently, notice,

00:01:42.173 --> 00:01:45.250
And that's how you know that you're

Without that particular configuration,

you don't have that

And that's why we weren't able to do this.

41
00:01:52.360 --> 00:01:54.920
Now, all I'm gonna do is

00:01:54.920 --> 00:01:59.480
And it's here that you also saw in

you don't have any

44
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:05.110
Even though I purchased it,

45
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:10.210
So now I can select get new numbers or get

46
00:02:12.000 --> 00:02:15.810
And it's just gonna take a moment and then

47
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:17.860
Now, I showed you where you could

00:02:17.860 --> 00:02:22.500
it's about the same thing, but
it's not exactly the same.

49
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:25.680
So I'm gonna select where I am,
which is inside of the Florida, and

00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:27.700
then the particular city here.

51

And then it says I can acquire a total

If I had nine phones that I really needed,

I'd just type the number nine.

But let me just be a little

I'll type in three

Then I can click Add.

57
00:02:46.170 --> 00:02:47.200
And it will take a look.

58
00:02:47.200 --> 00:02:50.150
And this is all live time at this point.

59
00:02:50.150 --> 00:02:51.850
So I have to wait on services.

60
00:02:51.850 --> 00:02:55.150
If they're not available, I just have to

61
00:02:55.150 --> 00:02:59.356
But here is where you can see, we're

62
00:02:59.356 --> 00:03:01.960
And now I selected three new numbers.

63
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:03.320
If I click show numbers,

64
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:07.010
here are the three available numbers

65
00:03:07.010 --> 00:03:09.322
Now, if I don't want,
to I can simple uncheck this.

00:03:09.322 --> 00:03:11.696
If I wanna acquire all of them, I can.

00:03:11.696 --> 00:03:13.312
And it depends on the number

Notice I have ten minutes left

00:03:16.690 --> 00:03:19.652
They're pretty much telling me that, look,

00:03:22.075 --> 00:03:23.630
Somebody else that comes

00:03:23.630 --> 00:03:26.260
if they wanna take those numbers,

So they don't really set it for long.

74
00:03:28.222 --> 00:03:33.178
I don't just get to say, just kinda set

75

That's pretty much it.

76

You can't keep them for like 12 hours or

You just have to be able
to select what you want.

78
00:03:40.703 --> 00:03:44.560
So let me go ahead and

00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:47.540
Now, I really didn't have

00:03:47.540 --> 00:03:55.180
I only bought two additional licenses for

00:03:55.180 --> 00:03:59.250
the PSTM, the publicly switched telephone
network, on the domestic calling plan.

82
00:03:59.250 --> 00:04:02.390
And once I did that,

A new thing also appeared up here,

Now, you might wonder,

85
00:04:09.840 --> 00:04:14.429
Well, let's say that Zach has had his
telephone number for 20 years and

00:04:14.429 --> 00:04:17.551
it's for his old business,
it's been working.

87
00:04:17.551 --> 00:04:21.032
And now that he's switching to

he's like,
do I have to get a new phone number?

89
00:04:23.770 --> 00:04:25.360
No, he really doesn't.

90
00:04:25.360 --> 00:04:29.010
He can instead just actually
port that number over, and

00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:32.731
now he can actually have his particular
number that he's been using, let's say

92
00:04:32.731 --> 00:04:36.050
it's his number to his professional
line that he wanted to keep using.

93
00:04:36.050 --> 00:04:37.046
He can still use that.

94
00:04:37.046 --> 00:04:41.473
He can actually take that number and
apply into Skype for Business and

95
00:04:41.473 --> 00:04:44.320
he's off and ready to go once that's done.

96
00:04:44.320 --> 00:04:48.912
Now, to finish this completion and
what we have to do is once we have this.

97
00:04:48.912 --> 00:04:51.220
And I already did a few numbers before.

98
00:04:51.220 --> 00:04:54.500
You can see where one has actually
been assigned to a user already,

99
00:04:54.500 --> 00:04:56.190
which is the one down here.

00:04:56.190 --> 00:04:58.210
And then there's the conference bridge.

101
00:04:58.210 --> 00:05:00.341
But all these other assigned numbers.

102
00:05:00.341 --> 00:05:04.250
So, let's say it's going

00:05:04.250 --> 00:05:09.160
I can click this particular number here,
let me not select this one here.

104
00:05:09.160 --> 00:05:14.650
I can click this number and
then go to assign, and it's gonna either

105
00:05:14.650 --> 00:05:20.290
balk at me or it's gonna say something
else, that everything is not ready.

106
00:05:20.290 --> 00:05:23.127
And what it means by if
you see where it says,

107
00:05:23.127 --> 00:05:27.057
you can't assign this until
you get an emergency location.

108
00:05:27.057 --> 00:05:29.943
Well, it lets you know that
before you can assign a number,

109
00:05:29.943 --> 00:05:32.380
you have to have at least
one emergency location.

110
00:05:32.380 --> 00:05:35.120
And they don't mean
an emergency telephone number,

111
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:37.152
they mean an actual physical location.

112
00:05:37.152 --> 00:05:40.660
So here is the actual address
to our physical building.

113
00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:44.740
And that is all due to like the 911
system and emergency numbers and

114
00:05:44.740 --> 00:05:47.050
how they end up dialing and everything.

115
00:05:47.050 --> 00:05:51.930
Now, you'll be able to enter in an actual
street address and whatever you want.

116
00:05:51.930 --> 00:05:55.270
Then it will go out and
try to validate the number.

117
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:58.459
If that number's not validated, it's not
going to allow you to assign a number.

118
00:05:58.459 --> 00:06:01.520
So it doesn't always have to be exact.

119
00:06:01.520 --> 00:06:04.969
It has to be near something that,
whatever their mapping system is,

120
00:06:04.969 --> 00:06:06.850
they have to be able to do.

121
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:09.960
The way to do that is you would
click on this plus sign and

122
00:06:09.960 --> 00:06:13.480
then you type in the name and
the address and you select the region.

123
00:06:13.480 --> 00:06:16.610
From that point,
it will allow you to do that.

124
00:06:16.610 --> 00:06:18.989
Now, I've already typed in mine,
so I'm not so worried about.

125
00:06:18.989 --> 00:06:21.190
And that's why it accepted right away.

126
00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:25.450
But once everything is done and
it's validated, then I can go back to

127
00:06:25.450 --> 00:06:29.810

128
00:06:29.810 --> 00:06:33.570
Once I assign it, now I have to

129
00:06:33.570 --> 00:06:35.696
Let's say it's Joey here for a moment.

130
00:06:35.696 --> 00:06:38.660
And I'm gonna tell it to search

131
00:06:39.950 --> 00:06:43.710
And in a moment, it says, hey,
I found one voice user, and that's Joey.

132
00:06:45.090 --> 00:06:49.911
And from here, once I get everything done,
emergency location,

133
00:06:49.911 --> 00:06:52.592
I have to assign that number as well.

134
00:06:52.592 --> 00:06:55.590
And now notice the save button appeared.

135
00:06:55.590 --> 00:07:00.280
If I forget to assign this, the save
button will not allow me to save it.

136
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:04.197
So now I have it with a physical
address and this number.

137
00:07:04.197 --> 00:07:07.070
Then I can click save
to this number as well.

138
00:07:07.070 --> 00:07:10.210
And that will allow me to
assign that number in.

139
00:07:10.210 --> 00:07:12.960
And now the changes have
been successfully saved.

140
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:14.550
You can see where it's pending.

141
00:07:14.550 --> 00:07:19.600
This may take a bit of time as well
before the number becomes active.

142
00:07:19.600 --> 00:07:23.060
So this can take a few minutes or
it can take several hours.

143
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:26.938
I normally would probably wait probably
overnight before I tell anybody,

144
00:07:26.938 --> 00:07:28.915
go ahead and start using that number.

145
00:07:28.915 --> 00:07:32.340
But sometimes they do allow you to
assign in it and works right away.

146
00:07:32.340 --> 00:07:36.821
But I would check and make sure that
it's actually not pending anymore.

147
00:07:36.821 --> 00:07:41.030
Once it's not pending,
it becomes activated, and

148
00:07:41.030 --> 00:07:44.290
also it becomes assigned at that point.

149
00:07:44.290 --> 00:07:45.779
And then you are ready to go.

150
00:07:45.779 --> 00:07:47.809
Once everything is ready to go,

151
00:07:47.809 --> 00:07:52.568
then you have now officially set up
a system that will begin to work for you.

152
00:07:52.568 --> 00:07:56.249
All these other numbers that you
have as you hire new people in,

153
00:07:56.249 --> 00:08:00.694
you can assign them the same way, give
them the location of your building for

154
00:08:00.694 --> 00:08:02.172
the emergency contact.

155
00:08:02.172 --> 00:08:06.150
And that will also give them that
access to be able to do that.

156
00:08:06.150 --> 00:08:10.950
So, that is kind of exactly
what we need to do to complete

157
00:08:10.950 --> 00:08:13.640
that portion of what we
were showing you for

158
00:08:13.640 --> 00:08:17.860
a lab setting inside of the Skype settings
that we've been talking about, the global

159
00:08:17.860 --> 00:08:22.360
settings that will help us out, making
sure that we do get everybody configured.

160
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:25.710
And of course the ability to use
a telephone that we can now assign.

161
00:08:25.710 --> 00:08:27.760
Now, the neat thing about the phones,
right.

162
00:08:27.760 --> 00:08:30.920
As you buy these phones,
you don't have to actually go in like,

163
00:08:30.920 --> 00:08:35.070
now I need to make sure that I
program this phone number in.

164
00:08:35.070 --> 00:08:40.901
All they need is their
Office 365 account and,

165
00:08:40.901 --> 00:08:46.330
on those phones, they just enter in
their email address and their passwords,

166
00:08:46.330 --> 00:08:49.050
and that will automatically
connect them to the right number,

167
00:08:49.050 --> 00:08:51.480
it will set up everything for them.

168
00:08:51.480 --> 00:08:53.700
There's not a ton of
configuration left for

169
00:08:53.700 --> 00:08:56.910
them to do as long as they
are connected online.

170
00:08:56.910 --> 00:08:59.390
And the other valuable thing about this,
Zach,

171
00:08:59.390 --> 00:09:02.110
is now they can take that handset and
phone.

172
00:09:02.110 --> 00:09:05.440
I don't know, I'm pretty sure somebody
does this, it wouldn't be me.

173
00:09:05.440 --> 00:09:09.290
But they can take that phone and
if they go on a business trip somewhere,

174
00:09:09.290 --> 00:09:13.399
they just have to plug in to a place
where there's an Internet connection and

175
00:09:13.399 --> 00:09:17.016
it will plug right back up and
that phone number will work for them.

176
00:09:17.016 --> 00:09:18.720
>> They'll be connected.
>> Exactly that way, yeah.

177
00:09:18.720 --> 00:09:22.990

This more than anything,

But when you put a device

By doing that,
you should be able to press enter and

now that should actually set it up to

424

Now, I haven't checked this part out.

It doesn't actually do anything here.

Now, let me click cancel cuz I really

it here cuz if I push it right now,

Let me just click off for that thing.

And let's see, I was in organization, so

it may also take a bit of time before

431

So just kinda realize it may not show

we do know that it did take the command.

We are able to see this.

00:25:01.420 --> 00:25:02.860
I don't know if I have

let's see if I have

Every once in awhile I get, let's see.

437

There we go.

Okay.
There you go, so

00:25:11.190 --> 00:25:13.090
right here it actually shows you.

So at least we are able to
verify this one very easily here

by realizing that we have

And it may take that period of time

back into the Web UI and doing

444

So, don't rush it, that's the only thing
that we can say right now especially about

446

There's a lot of configuration changes in
the last hour or so, Zach, between you and

I, I made three or four global changes,

not a change to a single user, but

and even though it's a small organization

450

You can imagine that if this
change affected 600 users,

451

2,000 users, it might take a bit
of time to actually change.

452
00:26:00.530 --> 00:26:01.480
And just with three, right?

453
00:26:01.480 --> 00:26:06.990
We've already seen limits of an hour or
24 hours before changes take place.

454
00:26:06.990 --> 00:26:10.380
So don't think that it
can't take a lot longer.

455
00:26:10.380 --> 00:26:15.005
Just kinda make sure that you
understand that that process on working

456
00:26:15.005 --> 00:26:20.270
with the the cloud, it is set it and
wait until the services take place.

457
00:26:20.270 --> 00:26:22.940
When it comes too extreme,
make sure you contact Microsoft and

they can help check that out too.

459
00:26:24.648 --> 00:26:28.910
But overall though those are some of
the other services that we need to pay

460
00:26:28.910 --> 00:26:31.910
attention to, to get everything ready.

461
00:26:31.910 --> 00:26:37.110
Now, there's a lot more for us to actually
cover in terms of these types of getting

462
00:26:38.760 --> 00:26:40.650
Skype for Business set up.

00:26:40.650 --> 00:26:44.220
We haven't even actually covered all
the other stuff that we have to do.

464
00:26:44.220 --> 00:26:48.070
If I wanna communicate with people that
don't have Skype for business, Justin,

465

and we still need to cover that but once
again, Zach, I have talked so much and so

long that I have run out of time.

>> But we covered a lot, we covered

we covered firewall considerations,
push notifications and

there will be more in Part Three
of Managing Skype Global Settings.

470
00:27:08.420 --> 00:27:10.210
Ronnie, thank you very much.

I'm your host Zach Memos for Enabling

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach demonstrate how to configure and allow non-Skype users in Skype for Business, PSTN Conferencing, and go over what is a Skpe Meeting Broadcast.
episodes.title: Manage Skype Global Settings Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

We're continuing on with

This is part three with our ITPro,

Ronnie, can you kinda quickly bring
us up to speed, if you can, and

13

>> All right, as we've taken a look,

we're talking essentially about all those
settings that we wanna be able to set up

15
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:45.020

16
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:48.120
Where we're configuring some
generalized settings here globally,

17
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:51.570

external users to be able to connect in.

18
00:00:51.570 --> 00:00:58.680
Being able to create custom notifications
or invites that we have available to us.

19
00:00:58.680 --> 00:01:01.580
As well as take a look at how
we manage those domains and

20
00:01:01.580 --> 00:01:03.250
allowing access to come in.

21
00:01:03.250 --> 00:01:07.300
We've also taken some time to take
a look at push notifications,

00:01:07.300 --> 00:01:10.050

23

And now it means that we're ready to

24
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:16.660
>> And in fact, I had a question for you.

00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:18.200
>> Okay.
>> So Skype for Business,

powerful tool, awesome, great to use.

27

What if you were trying to communicate
with, you wanna bring someone into your

Skype for Business conferencing whatever,
and they don't have Skype for Business?

>> Yeah, that's actually a great question.

30

Everything we've talked about so far works

Business users on one end, Skype for
Business users on the other end.

32

And you're connecting the Cloud

35

But not everybody has Skype for

00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:58.150

There are still a lot of companies

39
00:02:05.350 --> 00:02:08.320
A PST, on a publicly switched

40

And you may still do business with them.

41
00:02:11.890 --> 00:02:16.510
Well, if I am on my end using Skype for

Well, that means I have to

Business into that publicly

00:02:30.903 --> 00:02:34.982
So that even if I am on a telephonic

47

48
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:40.620

49
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:45.045

some technology in the middle of that that

50
00:02:45.045 --> 00:02:47.865

do what we want to.

51
00:02:47.865 --> 00:02:50.490
Once we start doing something like that,

52

we do have to actually integrate in some

And this is where licensing becomes

55
00:03:03.900 --> 00:03:08.780
So in this sense, you do have to kind
of decide for your company whether or

56
00:03:08.780 --> 00:03:12.620
not everybody is gonna get
a license to be able to do this.

57
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:16.242
Or whether only some people are going
to get a license to do this.

58
00:03:16.242 --> 00:03:21.109
Because it can add up in terms of how much
money that you're willing to spend and

59
00:03:21.109 --> 00:03:22.630
do this, okay?

60
00:03:22.630 --> 00:03:25.610
So you have to kind of
determine stuff like that.

61

But let's go ahead and
show you at least for

the licensing side what needs to

So on my screen here,

Notice that, I'm going full screen here,

Notice the one for Joey's account
right here, it has Skype for

00:03:56.400 --> 00:04:00.110
Business PSTN Domestic Calling and

71

Same thing if I hover over here for
Lance, Skype for

00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:15.380
Business PSTN Domestic Calling and
Office 365 Enterprise.

00:04:15.380 --> 00:04:20.730
And then for JT over here,

00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:25.380
These two will be able
to actually communicate

00:04:25.380 --> 00:04:29.540

But JT here in the middle

Now, if we wanted him to do that,

78
00:04:38.946 --> 00:04:41.253
If I select Justin's account,

It is in here just a moment we

80
00:04:45.538 --> 00:04:52.013
And then if I click on Edit under

81

82
00:04:57.661 --> 00:05:02.125
What I'm looking for are a couple of
options that will probably be off here if

00:05:02.125 --> 00:05:04.236
I, actually it's not showing up.

84
00:05:04.236 --> 00:05:08.960
But here's at least one option
that I need that is off.

85
00:05:08.960 --> 00:05:13.940
Notice right here where it says Skype for
Business PSTN Domestic Calling.

86
00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:17.750
And if I bring that over, you'll see
it's actually turned off right now.

87
00:05:17.750 --> 00:05:21.350
And I have not purchased
an additional license to give them.

88
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:23.913
So I can't just turn it on here,
and give him a license,

89
00:05:23.913 --> 00:05:27.254
cuz that would add in something that

90
00:05:27.254 --> 00:05:28.550
>> Hm.

91

>> But overall, though,
you need at least that to be turned

93
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:37.410
The other feature, I'm trying to see

00:05:37.410 --> 00:05:43.770

95
00:05:45.848 --> 00:05:49.709
So if I double-click on Joey's account,
and

00:05:49.709 --> 00:05:53.080
go to Edit under the Product Licensing.

97
00:05:56.230 --> 00:06:01.385
And expand out what features are on his,
we'll actually see if

I scroll down here the one that

99
00:06:06.453 --> 00:06:09.414
Skype for Business Cloud PBX.

100
00:06:09.414 --> 00:06:17.130
By default, the E5 account has this

00:06:17.130 --> 00:06:20.880
And you'll also notice Skype for

That's different than the one

00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:31.710
So I have to have both of

00:06:31.710 --> 00:06:35.820
So even the E5, which is the most

default, they won't be able to call out,

If they don't have this,

108
00:06:41.565 --> 00:06:46.795
which is an additional charge that you'll

109

Now what that gives you, though,
is the ability to take advantage

111
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:01.227
This is really that component,
that private branch exchange that says,

all right, Ronnie.

You are gonna connect into the world out
there, but for you to do so, it also

number, you have to be able to do that.

115
00:07:12.409 --> 00:07:16.200
And it gives you a whole
bunch of other things too.

116
00:07:16.200 --> 00:07:20.670
That Skype or that Skype PBX there.

00:07:20.670 --> 00:07:23.640
Let me scroll over here so

And this is why it's impressive,

So when you get this, and
I have this link inside of the notes so

don't worry if you're going like,

You'll actually be able to see it in your

But here, the PBX is a phone

But look at these features that you and

Call and answer by name and

126
00:07:48.386 --> 00:07:51.383
Call delegation, call on behalf of,

128
00:07:55.886 --> 00:08:00.950
Call transfer, Caller ID,

00:08:00.950 --> 00:08:05.430
Enables you to play your call or

130
00:08:05.430 --> 00:08:06.200
Distinctive Ringing,

00:08:06.200 --> 00:08:10.470

132
00:08:10.470 --> 00:08:14.730
Skype for Business using your desk

133
00:08:14.730 --> 00:08:19.080
Integrated dialing, Team calling,
Video calls, voicemail.

134
00:08:19.080 --> 00:08:22.950
That is a ton of features

00:08:22.950 --> 00:08:26.560
you just have,

136
00:08:26.560 --> 00:08:30.350
So it's not something that you have

137
00:08:30.350 --> 00:08:36.440
If you have that Cloud PBX set up for

138
00:08:36.440 --> 00:08:41.372
And it really does, once you integrate in
an actual phone system handset with this,

139
00:08:41.372 --> 00:08:44.480
you have those features available to you.

140
00:08:44.480 --> 00:08:47.320
To be able to connect outside though,

141
00:08:47.320 --> 00:08:51.750

142
00:08:51.750 --> 00:08:54.760
So once we verified that
we have those accounts

143
00:08:54.760 --> 00:08:56.910

we've talked about here.

144
00:08:56.910 --> 00:09:00.010
Let me see if I can zoom back up for

145
00:09:01.250 --> 00:09:04.390
Remember that this is what you're
looking for, is right there, okay?

146
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:10.640
If they don't have the one that

00:09:15.960 --> 00:09:20.525
If you have the E3, you can add in the

149
00:09:20.525 --> 00:09:24.260
Then you can add the Skype for
Business PSTN domestic calling.

150
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:28.240
There's a domestic and there's also
a domestic and international calling, too.

151
00:09:28.240 --> 00:09:31.510
Just depends on how much money
you're willing to spend.

152
00:09:31.510 --> 00:09:35.714
But you can do that per user, so this is
not something you enable globally for

153
00:09:35.714 --> 00:09:37.629

154
00:09:37.629 --> 00:09:43.810
Because not everybody needs a system
that should be able to do all that.

155
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:47.040
So for example like me,
I don't have a telephone number here.

156
00:09:47.040 --> 00:09:50.480
But we do have people right
here on ITProTV staff,

157
00:09:50.480 --> 00:09:54.540
that they definitely need to have
a phone that they use every single day.

158
00:09:54.540 --> 00:09:57.286
I'm not one of those guys, so
I don't have any Skype for

159
00:09:57.286 --> 00:10:00.741
Business domestic calling plan,
I don't have access to any of that.

160
00:10:00.741 --> 00:10:06.380
And I don't mind, cuz I really don't like
taking phone calls to tell you the truth.

161
00:10:06.380 --> 00:10:07.940
But at the least here,

162
00:10:07.940 --> 00:10:11.470
we do know that that actually
can be where we assign that up.

163
00:10:11.470 --> 00:10:13.065
And that makes it cheaper, in other words,

164
00:10:13.065 --> 00:10:17.540
it's a competitive pricing model that
Skype for Business is really offering.

165
00:10:17.540 --> 00:10:21.190
It's saying look, take all these features,
compare it to another system out there.

166
00:10:21.190 --> 00:10:24.820
And see if they'll give you the same
thing, where you put it for

167
00:10:24.820 --> 00:10:26.800
as many people as you want to.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie describe and configure Advanced Threat Protection.  They discuss what is, where to configure some of the settings then they demonstrate creating a safelink policy as an example.

And there's something
that we need to get into,

which of course is the idea of
advanced threat protection.

15
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:45.815
Now Cherokee, when we start talking about
the idea of advanced threat protection,

16
00:00:45.815 --> 00:00:49.407
hopefully there's only one question that
comes to your mind if you haven't heard

17
00:00:49.407 --> 00:00:52.156
about it before, which is?
>> What is advanced threat protection?

18
00:00:52.156 --> 00:00:54.730
>> That's right, yeah, I mean, who knows?

19
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:59.350
But that is actually a cool thing
that we have available to us

Now, before I get into that, right,
where do I find it, how do I get to it?

22
00:01:06.380 --> 00:01:09.560
I know those are all questions

23

But when it comes down to it,

24
00:01:10.820 --> 00:01:15.460
right, the way that we've always
treated in things like security, right.

25
00:01:15.460 --> 00:01:19.970
And security in the past year or so
has really moved to the forefront of just

26
00:01:19.970 --> 00:01:23.490
about all of IT in every area
that you can think about.

27
00:01:23.490 --> 00:01:26.340
It doesn't matter, security is

00:01:26.340 --> 00:01:30.270
the reason why, of course, is that there's
just so many different types of attacks.

29
00:01:30.270 --> 00:01:32.830
And we're losing information
in different ways, and

00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:35.560
we have to protect against them better

Ronnie, just historically knowing that,

32
00:01:39.990 --> 00:01:44.950
Hey, we're not gonna be running more
than one type of antimalware software on

33

34
00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:49.010
So just hearing advanced
threat protection,

35
00:01:49.010 --> 00:01:51.390
I'm kind of curious to see
where we're headed with this.

36
00:01:51.390 --> 00:01:55.635
Is this in lieu of something
like Windows Defender or

37
00:01:55.635 --> 00:01:59.090
third-party software,
in addition to, does it conflict?

38
00:01:59.090 --> 00:02:00.490
So lots of questions here, and

39
00:02:00.490 --> 00:02:04.720
so I guess, where's a good place to start?
>> When you start thinking about questions

40

like that, that's actually a great place
to start and start to talk about, right?

41
00:02:09.210 --> 00:02:12.250
Does that mean we don't have to run
something like Windows Defender anymore,

42
00:02:12.250 --> 00:02:19.590
or any type of antimalware and
antiviral type of software on my computer?

43
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:20.610
Not necessarily, but

44
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:24.620
you've gotta remember that computing has
changed over the past several years.

45
00:02:24.620 --> 00:02:27.170
Most of us stay inside of
a corporate organization.

46
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:31.630
We're not just running software that's
managed only internally anymore.

47
00:02:31.630 --> 00:02:36.610
And it's because Office 365 essentially
is a cloud platform for us.

48
00:02:36.610 --> 00:02:40.910
And we are connecting from our own
machines, which we do tend to run

49
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:45.605
antimalware of some sort and antiviral
software, to protect our own machines.

50
00:02:45.605 --> 00:02:49.157
Well, what happens when we

51
00:02:49.157 --> 00:02:51.602
we still need that type of protection?

52
00:02:51.602 --> 00:02:56.040
And this is where the advanced
threat protection really comes in.

53
00:02:56.040 --> 00:02:58.678
It really bridges the gap that we
have where things are actually

54

just protected in the cloud, and
they're protected on your machine.

55
00:03:01.689 --> 00:03:03.894
Well, what about the in between points,
and

56
00:03:03.894 --> 00:03:06.691
what about other things that
actually end up happening?

57
00:03:06.691 --> 00:03:10.041
So advanced threat protection
really takes a look at it, and

58
00:03:10.041 --> 00:03:13.537
it really does center around

59
00:03:13.537 --> 00:03:17.021
Because that's still kind
of the communication,

60
00:03:17.021 --> 00:03:22.830
the blood of most organizations in terms

61
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:26.618
If email stops, and we've said it again
over and over again even in this series,

62
00:03:26.618 --> 00:03:28.746
and just about every
series I've ever done.

63
00:03:28.746 --> 00:03:31.573
Is that if you wanna get people upset,
printers and

64
00:03:31.573 --> 00:03:32.531
emails.
>> [LAUGH]

65
00:03:32.531 --> 00:03:33.868
>> Make sure they can't print,

66
00:03:33.868 --> 00:03:37.105
make sure they think that they've
lost an email, they will get upset.

67
00:03:37.105 --> 00:03:41.460
Well, the same thing, then,
if we don't protect that information,

68
00:03:41.460 --> 00:03:44.560
whether it's the content within it,
or whether they're getting spoofed or

69
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:47.580
whatever it might be, or
this is where we have problems.

70
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:52.175
And Office 365 has kind of reshaped
the way that they've done some of their

71
00:03:52.175 --> 00:03:54.090
protections to make it better.

72
00:03:54.090 --> 00:03:57.898
And that's why they call it
advanced threat protection now.

73
00:03:57.898 --> 00:04:00.709
Because now they're not only
looking at just the idea of email,

74
00:04:00.709 --> 00:04:02.750
because you're connected in Office 365.

75
00:04:02.750 --> 00:04:07.630
They want that same type of support for
things like your Skype for

76
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:11.400
Business Online, which I couldn't
remember and I'm telling you wrong.

77
00:04:11.400 --> 00:04:14.930
It's the OneDrive for Business is
what they want that protection for,

78
00:04:14.930 --> 00:04:18.070
as well as SharePoint, and
then, of course, Exchange.

79
00:04:18.070 --> 00:04:21.030
And they want that all managed
underneath one umbrella, and

80
00:04:21.030 --> 00:04:22.780
that's what advanced
threat protection does.

81
00:04:22.780 --> 00:04:24.840
It no longer is just about email, but

82
00:04:24.840 --> 00:04:30.180
now it actually allows you to also
protect things like even your own Office

83
00:04:30.180 --> 00:04:35.020
2016 products that you have available to
you, and that's what we end up seeing.

84
00:04:35.020 --> 00:04:38.800
So when it comes to Office 365
advanced threat protection,

85
00:04:38.800 --> 00:04:40.490
we're actually starting
to see more of this,

86
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:44.620
where it does provide things like
technology that we call Safelink, okay.

87
00:04:44.620 --> 00:04:48.780
That allows us to protect links that we
end up seeing not only in our emails, but

88
00:04:48.780 --> 00:04:51.890
also in our own Office products,
such as a document that comes in, and

89
00:04:51.890 --> 00:04:55.050
there's a link that's
actually right there for us.

90
00:04:55.050 --> 00:04:59.740
It allows, in the email part,
to also do for safe attachments.

91

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie take a look at creating customized policies against malware and spam.  They demonstrate where to configure them and show how to set them up too.
episodes.title: Customize Malware and Spam Protection

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie take a look at using connection filters.  Connections filters provide a means for us to allow or block emails based on IP addressing.  They show where the options are located and discuss each option.  The team also shows how to setup a IP Allow List and IP Block list using the O365 Portal.
episodes.title: Customize Connection Filters

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie continue with the demonstration of setting up connection filters.  This time the demonstrate connecting and using powershell to do so.  They show how to connect to Exchange Online.  They demonstrate how to verify, create and modify a connection filter through the powershell.
episodes.title: Customize Connection Filters Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Ronnie discuss the use of content filters.  They talk about some of the differences between connection filters and content filters.  Using the O365 portal, they show where and what to configure when customizing content filters.  The review all the options found within the configuration page.
episodes.title: Customize Content Filters

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie continue with customizing content filters.  Instead of configuring using the management portal, they do so by connecting powershell to connect to Exchange Online.  They configure a content filter policy using powershell
episodes.title: Customize Content Filters Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce the use of connectors to send emails through O365.  They describe common scenarios and whether or not your organization needs to use connectors and what must be considered to do so. Using the O365 portal, they demonstrate now to configure one of the two connectors that need to be created for this work between on-prem Exchange and O365.
episodes.title: Enable External Mail Flow Topologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue with the lab demonstration.  This demonstration, by the team, configures the on-prem exchange with the send connectors.  They show how to access the on-prem EAC to configure through that portal and ultimately they demonstrate the powershell script to configure the send connector work through 0365.
episodes.title: Enable External Mail Flow Topologies Part 2

topics.title: Plan for Exchange Online and Skype for Business Online

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the use of Microsoft Teams.  Teams will be succeeding Skype for Business as the main messaging and communication software within O365, according to the team.  They demonstrate the interface and talk about what is need to implement microsoft teams for the tenant.
episodes.title: Implement Microsoft Teams

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the use of Microsoft Teams.  Teams will be succeeding Skype for Business as the main messaging and communication software within O365, according to the team.  They demonstrate the interface and talk about what is need to implement microsoft teams for the tenant.
episodes.title: Implement Microsoft Teams Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the use of powerapps for business.  They  discuss the fact that a company may want to create an customized app for line of business data.  These apps can created for tablets or phones and published for access.  They show that apps can be created using templates or from scratch.
episodes.title: Implement Microsoft Flow and PowerApps

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the use of Microsoft flow to help a user create work flows for data or approval process. It's purpose is designed around automating task.  They show the use of templates as a good starting point to develop a flow.  They also mention the subscription requirement for the use of Microsoft Flow
episodes.title: Implement Microsoft Flow and PowerApps Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the context for using staff hub and what it is.  They also discusses the provisioning of it and account needed.  In the demonstration, they show how to use it to manage staff and then also how to configure it administratively.
episodes.title: Configure and Manage Microsoft StaffHub

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie Discuss the proliferation of cloud storage and ontrol of cloud storage.  They show how to configure storage quotas using the portal and begin to show now to modify those quotas using powershell.
episodes.title: Configure Storage and Access Control

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue with demonstrating configuring OneDrive for Business and setting up access control through the portal.  The show all the options available for restricting access through sharing and using compliance to setup alerts and device access control.
episodes.title: Configure Storage and Access Control Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie configure Document deletion polcies.  They emphasize the use of the Security & Compliance with Retention Policies as being the preferred method to create and configure them.  They also demonstrate how to get to the Document Deletion Policy Center in Sharepoint Online to create a policy if needed or to support legacy and on prem Sharepoint.
episodes.title: Configure Document Deletion Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss managing OneDrive for Business.  The team review the OneDrive Admin Center configuration options.  They demonstrate how to configure the network bandwidth options and show where to set alerts in the security &c compliance center.
episodes.title: Manage and Migrate OneDrive for Business

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show how to migrate on-prem files to OneDrive for Business using powershell.  They discuss some of the considerations and the options used in the powershell scripts.
episodes.title: Manage and Migrate OneDrive for Business Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie review the configuration of eDiscovery and show options in the Advanced eDiscovery.  They show how to configure and use eDiscovery and some of the options available in Advanced eDiscovery.
episodes.title: Configure eDiscovery and Advanced eDiscovery

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie give an overview of the security and compliance center.  They demonstrate how to setup advanced data governance through a retention policy.  They also show where and how to enable secure store for credentials to 3rd party data sources.
episodes.title: Configure Office 365 Security and Governance

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie give an overview of the security and compliance center. The talk about the need for accessing 3rd party data to display in sharepoint and the credentials needed to so.   They show where and how to enable secure store for credentials to 3rd party data sources.  This a common usage scenario when that data doesn't reside in your site.
episodes.title: Configure Office 365 Security and Governance Pt.2
